Use the optional farming method only for income from an agricultural business.

You can report less than your total income from farm and nonfarm real net income, but not less than your real nonfarm net income. If you use both of these optional methods, you can report no more than $6,920 as your combined net income from self-employment.
If you use a tax year other than the calendar year, you must use the tax rate and the income limit in effect at the beginning of your tax year.

If you file Form 1040-SS, you may enter the self-employment tax on line 3 and attach the SE tax return to your form. If you need to pay self-employment taxes, you may file Form 1040, 1040-SR or 1040-SS, as appropriate (with the SE attachment), but you may not otherwise have to file a federal income tax return.

If you are filing a joint return, you cannot file a joint SE-annex.This is true regardless of whether one or both of you have income subject to tax on self-employment.If you both have income subject to tax on self-employment, you must each complete a separate SE-annex.Attach both annexes to the joint return.

If you have more than one occupation or business, you must combine the net profits (or losses) of each business to calculate your self-employment taxes.A loss from one business will reduce your profit from another business.Please submit a (1) Schedule SE showing self-employment income, but submit a separate Schedule C or Schedule F for each business.
This chapter explains the review, appeal, collection and reimbursement processes.

We accept most tax returns as taxpayers file them. If we require information about your tax return or select it for review, this does not mean that you are dishonest. The review or investigation may or may not result in the payment of additional taxes. We may close your case without making changes to you, or you may receive a refund. The process of selecting a tax return for review usually begins in one of two ways. One is by using computer programs to identify returns that may have incorrect amounts. These programs may be based on informative returns, such as Forms 1099 and W-2, on studies of past audits, or on certain issues identified by other special projects. Another way is to use information from tax compliance projects that indicate that a return may include incorrect amounts. These sources may include public journals, newspapers, and individual records. If we publish the returns, we may include the records and explain how to follow up with the auditors, and then we may use a summary of these returns, such as Claims 556, to review these returns, and to provide a summary of these claims, and to explain how to use these returns during the Refunds and Refunds, which are carried out by the individual, and then we may use the information to rectify these claims, and to rectify these claims, and to the extent that such claims are forfeasibility, and to the extent that such claims are reviewed.

If you do not agree with the changes proposed by the examiner, you may appeal to the IRS Independent Appeals Office. Most disagreements can be resolved without incurring the time and expense of going to court. Your rights of appeal are explained in detail in Publication 5, Your Rights of Appeal and How to Prepare a Protest If You Disagree, and Publication 556. If you do not wish to use the Independent Appeals Office or if you disagree with its determinations, you may appeal your case to the U.S. Tax Court, the U.S. Court of Federal Claims, or the U.S. Court of First Instance. If you have not properly complied with these administrative procedures, including the IRS's determination that you have been unfairly treated in your administrative record, you may have the right to reinstate your administrative expenses and to recover your costs if you are unable to meet the IRS's administrative record and other due process requirements. If you have failed to meet the IRS's obligations, you may be entitled to recover your costs by filing your claim with us and by taking your claim to the IRS for a court hearing, where you have been granted the right to do so.
The rights of the claimant to appeal the collection are set out in detail in Publication 1660, Rights for the Appeal of Collection.

In general, you and your spouse are jointly and individually responsible for paying the full amount of any tax, interest, or penalty owed on your joint return. To request relief from any liability related to your spouse (or former spouse), you must file Form 8857, Application for Innocent Spouse Relief. In some cases, you may need to file Form 8857 within 2 years of the date the IRS first attempted to collect the tax from you.

If you are a taxpayer, you are entitled to receive a tax refund if you are not able to pay your tax bill. If you are a taxpayer, you are entitled to receive a tax refund if you are unable to pay your tax bill. If you are a taxpayer, you are entitled to receive a tax refund if you are unable to pay your tax bill. If you are a taxpayer, you are entitled to receive a tax refund if you are unable to pay your tax bill.

You may file a refund claim if you believe you have paid too much tax. You generally have to file the claim within 3 years from the date you filed your original return or 2 years from the date you paid the tax, whichever is later. Publication 556 contains additional information on refunds. If you were entitled to receive a refund but did not file a tax return, then you will have to file a refund claim within a period of 2 years from the date you paid the tax to receive the refund. The law generally stipulates that interest is paid on the amount of your refund if you are not paid within a period of 45 days from the date you filed your tax return or claimed the tax refund.

If you have questions about a tax matter, need help preparing your tax return, or want to download publications, forms, or instructions for free, visit IRS.gov to find resources that can help you immediately.

After you have received all of your pay and income receipts (Forms W-2, W-2G, 1099-R, 1099-MISC, 1099-NEC, etc.); unemployment income receipts (by mail or in digital format), or other government payment receipts (Form 1099-G); and interest, dividend, and retirement receipts from banks and investment companies (Forms 1099), you can find options for preparing and filing your tax return.

Taxpayers who need information about our accessibility services can call 833-690-0598. The Accessibility Helpline can answer questions related to current and future accessibility products and services available in alternative media formats (e.g., braille, large print, audio file, etc.). The Accessibility Helpline does not have access to your IRS account. For help with tax law, refunds, or account-related questions, please visit IRS.gov/en/help.

You will need an IRS online account (OLA) to complete mobile-friendly forms that require signatures. You will have the option to submit your forms online or download a copy to mail. You will need scans of your documents to support your filing.

Access IRS.gov/Account to securely view information about your federal tax account. See the amount you owe and a breakdown by tax year. See your payment plan details or request a new payment plan. Make a payment or review the last 5 years of your payment history and any outstanding or scheduled payments. Access your tax records, including key data from your most recent tax return and their transcripts. View digital copies of certain IRS notices. Approve or reject authorization requests from tax professionals. See your address in our records or manage your communication preferences.

With an online account, you can access a variety of information that can help you during the tax filing season.You can get a transcript, review your last tax return you filed, and get the amount of your adjusted gross income.Create or access your online account at IRS.gov/account.

Tax-related identity theft happens when someone steals your personal information to commit tax fraud. Your taxes may be affected if your Social Security number (SSN) is used to file a fraudulent tax return or to claim a refund or credit. The IRS does not initiate communications with taxpayers through email, text messages (which include short links), phone calls, or social media to ask them or verify personal or financial information. This includes requests for personal identification numbers (PIN), passwords, or similar information for credit cards, bank accounts, or other financial accounts.
In addition, the IRS offers Free File Fillable Forms, which can be completed online and then filed electronically regardless of how much income you have.

The IRS cannot issue refunds before mid-February for tax returns claiming the earned income credit (EIC) or the additional child tax credit (ACTC).This restriction applies to the full refund, not just the portion related to these credits.

IRS Direct Pay: Individuals can pay their tax bills or make estimated tax payments directly from their checking or savings accounts. Use of IRS Direct Pay is free; you will not have to pay any fees for its use. Receipts received by debit card, credit card, or digital wallet: Choose an approved processor to pay online or by phone. Electronic withdrawal of funds: Schedule a payment when you file your federal tax return using electronic tax return preparation software or through a professional electronic federal tax payment system.
Use the Offer in Compromise Pre-Qualifier to see if you can settle your tax debt for less than the amount you owe. For more information about the Offer in Compromise program, visit IRS.gov/OIC/OIC.
If you are a self-employed business, a partnership, or an S corporation, you can view tax information in the IRS records and do more with a business tax account.
You can visit the SBA website at SBA.gov. By browsing the SBA website, you will find a variety of information of interest to small businesses.
To find the location nearest you, visit the SBA website or call the SBA information service.
Call the GPO toll-free at 866-512-1800 or 202-512-1800 in the Washington, DC area.

This chapter explains the business taxes you may have to pay and the forms you may have to file.It also explains the taxpayer identification numbers (TINs).Table 1-1 indicates the benefits of filing your return electronically.Table 1-2 indicates the federal taxes you may have to pay, your due dates for payment, and the forms you use to file them.Table 1-3 provides checklists that indicate the regular forms and attachments you may have to file if you close your business.
This part explains whether and when you have to file an income tax return and how to pay taxes.
If you had less than $400 in net self-employment income, you still have to file an income tax return if you meet any of the other filing requirements listed in the Instructions for Form 1040.

File your tax return using Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR and attach a Schedule C. Write down the net profit or loss from Schedule C on Schedule 1 (Form 1040). Use Schedule C to calculate the net profit or loss of your business. If you operated more than one business as the sole owner of a business, you must attach a separate Schedule C for each business.

If you file an electronic return using tax preparation software or the services of a tax professional, you will sign your return using the IRS's Personal Identification Number (PIN) self-selection method. If you are married filing a joint return, you and your spouse will need to create a PIN for each other and use it as your electronic signatures. To create a PIN, you must choose your Adjusted Gross Income (AGI) from your original income tax return (no longer registered in the U.S. tax return, but aged 16 or older at the end of 2024.
In most states, you can file a state tax return electronically at the same time as your federal tax return.For more information, contact your state tax agency, a tax professional, or visit IRS.gov.

You can have your refund check mailed to you, or you can have the refund deposited directly into your checking or savings account. With the IRS e-file system, your refund will be issued in half the time as with a paper tax return processing. Most refunds are issued in less than 21 days.

As with a paper tax return, you may not receive your full refund if you (or your spouse, if filing jointly) owe certain amounts back or due, such as federal taxes, state taxes, a student loan or child support. You will be notified if the refund you claimed was used to offset your debts. You may file an aggrieved spouse claim on Form 8379, Injured Spouse Allocation; or on Form 8857, Application for Innocent Spouse Relief, to recover part or all of a joint refund transferred to pay your spouse's separate liabilities.

The IRS cannot issue refunds before mid-February 2025 for returns claiming the earned income credit or the additional child tax credit.This applies to the full refund, not just the portion related to these credits.

If your return shows that you owe taxes, you must pay them by the due date of your return (regardless of any extension to file the return) to avoid late payment penalties and interest. April 15, 2025 is the due date for filing the income tax return for the year 2024 if you use a calendar year. You have many options for making your payment, including scheduling an electronic withdrawal of funds from your checking or savings account or using a debit or credit card.

You will be asked to complete Form 8879, Signature Authorization to File a Return through IRS e-file, to authorize the provider to enter your self-selected PIN into your return. Depending on the provider and the specific services requested, you may be charged a fee. To find an authorized IRS e-file provider near you, go to IRS.gov/eFile and click on English.

All you need to file your tax return through the IRS e-file system is a computer with Internet access. If you use your personal computer, you can file your return via e-file from your home at any time of the day or night. To complete the process, sign your return electronically by using your self-selected PIN.
If your AGI was $84,000 or less in 2024, you can use free computer tax software to prepare and file your tax return electronically.

Some businesses offer their employees, members or customers the opportunity to file their returns free of charge through the e-file system.Others charge for this service.Ask your employer or financial institution if they offer the use of the IRS e-file system as a benefit to employees, members or customers.

For the calendar year 2024, the due date for filing Form 1040 or 1040-SR is no later than April 15, 2025. If you use a fiscal year (explained in Chapter 2), the due date for filing your tax return is the 15th day of the 4th month after your fiscal year ends. If you file your return late, you may have to pay penalties and interest. If you cannot file your tax return on time, use Form 4868, Automatic Request for Prolongation to File the United States Personal Income Tax Return, to apply for an automatic 6-month extension.

The self-employment tax consists of Social Security and Medicare taxes primarily for self-employed individuals. It is similar to the Social Security and Medicare taxes that are withheld from payroll checks of most people earning wages and salaries. If you earned income from work as a statutory employee, you do not pay self-employment tax on that income. Social Security and Medicare taxes should have already been withheld from that income.

Social Security benefits are available to self-employed individuals in the same way as to individuals who become salaried or salaried. Your self-employment tax payments contribute to your coverage under the Social Security system. Social Security coverage provides you with retirement benefits, disability benefits, survivor benefits, and Medicare benefits. Make sure you declare all of your self-employment income. If you do not declare all of your income, it could result in your Social Security benefits being less when you retire.

You must be insured (enrolled) in the Social Insurance scheme before you can start receiving Social Insurance benefits.You will be insured if you have accumulated the required number of credits (also called coverage quarters), as explained below.

In 2024, you received a credit, up to a maximum of four credits, for every $1,730 ($1,810 in 2025) of income subject to Social Security tax payment. Thus, in 2024, if you had $6,920 in income (from self-employment and wages) that was subject to Social Security tax payment, you received four credits ($6,920 ÷ $1,730). For an explanation of the number of credits you must have to be insured and the benefits available to you and your family under the Social Security program, please consult your nearest SSA office.
The self-employment income tax rate on net earnings is 15.3% (12.4% of Social Security income tax plus 2.9% of Medicare income tax).

Only the first $168,600 of the combination of your wages, tips, and net income in 2024 are subject to the payment of any combination of the 12.4% Social Security portion of self-employment taxes, Social Security tax, or the retirement income tax level 1 for railroad employees. All of your wages, tips, and net income combined in 2024 are subject to any combination of the 2.9% Medicare portion of self-employment taxes, Social Security income tax, or the income income tax level 1 retirement income tax for railroad employees. If your wages and tips are subject to Social Security income tax or the income tax level 1 retirement income tax for railroad employees, or both, and total at least $168,600, you do not pay the 12.4% Social Security income income tax line for self-employment taxes on any of your income for your own income. The excise taxes reported on Form 720, Quarterly Federal Excise Tax Return, consist of several broad categories of taxes, including the following: Environmental taxes on the sale or use of ozone-depleting chemicals and imported products containing or manufactured with those chemicals; Communications and air transportation taxes; Fuel taxes; Taxes on the initial retail sale of heavy trucks, trailers, and tractors; Manufacturer taxes on the sale or use of a variety of different items; Taxes on the services of the former underground tannery.
There is a federal tax on the use of certain trucks, tractor-trailers, and buses on public roads. The tax applies to vehicles that have a taxable gross weight of 55,000 pounds or more.
If you are a taxpayer who has to file a quarterly consumer goods tax return on Form 720, you may have to file your consumer goods taxes before the filing deadline.

When you make or receive payments in your business, you may need to report them to the IRS using information returns.The IRS compares the payments shown on the information returns with those shown on each person's income tax returns to see if the payments were included as income.You must give the payee or payer a copy of each information return you are required to file.In addition to the forms described below, you may need to use other returns to report certain types of payments or transactions.For more details on the information returns and when you need to file them, see the General Instructions for Certain Information Returns.
You will also use Form 1099-MISC to declare your sales of $5,000 or more in consumer products to a person who will resell them at any other place other than a permanent retail establishment.

You also have to file Form 1099-NEC for each person who has withheld any federal income tax (reported in box 4) under the additional withholding rules regardless of the amount of the payment.If you use Form 1099-NEC to report sales totaling $5,000 or more of consumer products, then you must file Form 1099-NEC with the IRS by January 31.
You must file Form W-2 to declare payments made to your employees, such as wages, tips, and other types of compensation; and income tax withholdings; and Social Security and Medicare taxes.

The law provides the following penalties for failure to file Form 1099-MISC, Form 1099-NEC, or Form W-2 or for failure to report information in the correct manner. For more information, see the General Instructions for Certain Information Returns. The statute provides that the penalty for failure to file a tax return is the following: "Failure to file the required information by the due date, failure to include all required information, or failure to report the incorrect information".

These fines will not be applied if you can prove that the failure was due to reasonable cause and not wilful negligence.In addition, there is no penalty for failing to include all the necessary information, or for including incorrect information, in a de minimis (minimum) number of returns if you correct the errors by 1 August of the year in which the deadline for submitting returns expires. (A de minimis number of returns is the greater of 10 or 1⁄2 (half) of 1% of the total number of returns you are required to submit for the year).

You must file Form 8300, Report of Cash Payments in Excess of $10,000 Received in an Occupation or Business, if you receive more than $10,000 in cash in a single transaction, or in two or more related business transactions. Cash includes U.S. and foreign currency and foreign exchange. It also includes certain monetary instruments, such as cashier's and traveler's checks, as well as money orders. Cash does not include checks drawn from an individual's personal account (personal checks).

There are civil and criminal penalties, including up to 5 years imprisonment, for failing to file Form 8300, filing (or having filed) a false or fraudulent Form 8300 or for structuring a transaction so as to evade reporting requirements.

You must calculate your taxable income and file an income tax return for an annual accounting period called the tax year.In addition, you must consistently use an accounting method that clearly shows your income and expenses for that tax year.
Unless you are required to use a specific tax year, you adopt the tax year when you file your first income tax return using that tax year.

If you file your first income tax return using the calendar tax year and later open a business as a sole proprietor of a business, you must continue to use the calendar tax year, unless you receive approval from the IRS to change it or are otherwise allowed to make the change without the IRS's approval. For more information, see Changing tax year, below. If you adopt the calendar tax year, you must keep your books and records, and declare your income and expenses for the period from January 1 to December 31 of each year.

A tax year is a period of 12 consecutive months that ends on the last day of any month except December. A 52- or 53-week tax year is a tax year that varies from 52 to 53 weeks but does not have to end on the last day of a month. If you adopt a tax year, you must keep your books and records, and declare your income and expenses using the same tax year. For more information on tax years, including a 52- or 53-week tax year, see Publication 538.

If you qualify to apply for automatic approval, you will not have to pay an administrative fee. If you do not qualify for automatic approval, you will have to apply for a decision. See the Instructions for Form 1128 for information on administrative fees if you apply for a decision.

An accounting method is a set of rules that are used to determine when and how to declare income and expenses. Your accounting method includes not only the general accounting method that you use, but also the accounting classification that you use for any substantial item. You choose an accounting method for your business when you file your first income tax return that includes a Schedule C for the business. After that, if you want to change your accounting method, you will usually need to get approval from the IRS. See Change in Accounting Method, below.
You must use the same accounting method to calculate your taxable income and keep your books and accounts, and you must use an accounting method that clearly shows your income.

To obtain approval, you must file Form 3115.You may obtain approval from the IRS to change your accounting method under the automatic change procedures or the advance consent request procedures.You may have to pay a user fee.For more information, see the Instructions for Form 3115.

The IRS may require a user fee for a request that is filed under an automatic change procedure that is generally covered by the Revenue Procedure 2015-13 as found on page 419 of the Internal Revenue Bulletin 2015-5 (IRB/2015-05_IRBRP#2015-13 (or its successor). Generally, you must use Form 3115 to request an automatic change. For more information, see the Instructions for Form 3115 (see the instructions for the use of the IRS's Revenue Procedure 2015-13) which is available at IRS.gov.

You can account for business and personal items using different accounting methods.For example, you can calculate your business income using a cash method, even though you use the cash method to calculate your personal items.

If you have two or more separate and distinct businesses, you may use different accounting methods for each one, as long as the method clearly reflects the income of each business.They are considered separate and distinct only if you keep totally separate books and records for each business.

Most individuals and many sole proprietors of a business who do not have inventories use the cash-based method because they find it easier to keep cash-based records. However, if you need to carry inventory to account for your income, you will generally need to use the accrual method of accounting for sales and purchases, unless you are a small business taxpayer (defined later in this chapter). For more information, see Inventories, below.

Under the cash method, you include in your gross income all items of income that you actually or implicitly receive during the tax year. If you receive goods or services, you must include their fair market value in income.

You receive income implicitly when an amount is credited to your account or made available to you without any restrictions.You do not need to be in possession of the money.If you authorize someone else to be your agent and receive income on your behalf, you are deemed to have received it when your agent receives it.

You cannot withhold cheques or defer taking possession of similar goods from one tax year to another to avoid paying income tax.You must declare income in the year you receive the goods or when they are made available to you without restriction.
Receipt of a cheque that is valid at the end of the tax year is, implicitly, receipt of income for that year, even though you cannot change or deposit the cheque until the following year.

If someone else pays off your debts or if your creditors cancel them, you may have to declare all or part of that debt relief as income. If you receive income in this way, you receive the income implicitly when the debt is cancelled or settled.

If you include an amount in your income and in a later year you have to pay it back in whole or in part, you can usually deduct the refund in the year you do so. If you pay back more than $3,000, a special rule applies.

Under the cash method, you generally deduct expenses in the tax year in which you actually pay them, including business expenses for which the obligation is disputed.However, you may not be able to deduct an expense paid in advance or you may have to capitalize certain costs, as explained below under Uniform Capitalisation Rules.

Under a revenue-based method, you generally declare your income in the year you earn it and deduct or capitalize your expenses in the year you incur them. The purpose of a revenue-based method is to make the revenue and expenses match in the correct year.

Under a derivative accounting method, you generally include an amount in your gross income for the tax year in which all the conditions establishing your entitlement to receive the income have occurred, and you can determine the amount with reasonable accuracy. For a taxpayer with an applicable financial statement or other financial statement as specified by the Secretary, the proof of all events for a gross income item is deemed to be satisfied at the latest when it is accounted for in an applicable financial statement or some other similar financial statement.
The following are special rules that apply to advance payments, estimated revenue and changes in the service fee schedule.

If you include a reasonable estimate in your gross income and then determine that the exact amount is different, take the difference into account in the tax year in which you determine the difference.

If you perform services at a basic rate specified in a contract, you have to accrue income on the basis of the basic rate, even if you agree to receive payments at a lower rate until you complete the services and then receive the difference.

If you receive an advance payment, you may choose to defer the inclusion of the advance payment in your income until the next tax year. You cannot defer the inclusion of the payment beyond that tax year. For more information, see Publication 538 and section 451 of the Internal Revenue Code.

In general, you cannot deduct or capitalize a business expense until the economic return has occurred. If your expense relates to goods or services provided to you, or to your use of goods, the economic return occurs when you are provided the goods or services, or as you use the goods. If your expense relates to goods or services you provide to others, the economic return occurs as you provide the goods or services. An exception allows certain recurring items to be treated as if they had been incurred during a tax year, even though the economic return did not occur. For more information on economic performance, see Economic Performance under the Accrual Method in Publication 538.

When the production, purchase, or sale of merchandise constitutes an income-generating activity for your business, you generally have to account for inventories at the beginning and end of your tax year, unless you are a small business taxpayer. If you have to account for inventory, you generally have to use the accrual method of accounting for your purchases and sales.

You cannot deduct business expenses and interest owed to a person related to you who uses the cash-based accounting method until you make the payment and the corresponding amount can be included in the gross income of the related person. For the purposes of this rule, determine the relationship or relationship as of the end of the tax year for which the expenses or interest would otherwise be deductible. If a deduction is not allowed under this rule, the rule will continue to apply even if your relationship or relationship with the person ends before the expenses or interest can be included in the gross income of that person. Related persons include your immediate family members, including brothers and sisters (whether of the same parents or of the same parents or of the same parents), your spouse, your ancestors, and your lineal descendants. For a list of other related persons, see section 267 of the United States Tax Code.

Generally, you can use any combination of accounting methods, whether cash-based, accrual-based, and other special methods, if the combination clearly shows your income and expenses, and you use the method consistently. However, the following restrictions apply: If you need to keep an inventory to account for your income, you will generally have to use the accrual-based accounting method for sales and purchases. (However, see Inventories, below). You can use the cash-based accounting method for all other items of income and expenses.
Generally, if you produce, buy or sell goods in your business, you must keep inventory and use the accrual method of accounting for the purchase and sale of goods.

If you are a small business taxpayer, you may choose not to keep inventory, but you still have to use an accounting method for inventory that clearly reflects revenue. If you choose not to keep inventory, you will not be deemed not to clearly reflect revenue if your accounting method for inventory treats inventory as non-incidental materials or supplies, or it conforms to your financial accounting treatment of inventories. However, if you choose to keep inventory, you generally have to use an accrual-based accounting method and value the inventory each year to determine the cost of goods sold in Part III of Annex C.

You qualify as a small business taxpayer if (a) you have average annual gross revenues of $30 million or less during the preceding 3 tax years and (b) you are not a tax haven (as defined in section 448 (d)) (3). If your business has not existed during the entire 3 tax year period used to calculate the average gross revenues, base your average on the period it actually existed, and if your business has a predecessor entity, include the predecessor entity's gross revenues from the 3 tax year period when calculating your average gross revenues. If your business (or predecessor entity) had short tax years for any of the years in the 3 tax year period, then write off your business's gross revenues for the short tax years that are part of the 3 tax year period. See Publication 538 for more information.
If you want to change your accounting method for the inventory, you must submit Form 3115, Application for Change in Accounting Method.

If you are required to account for inventories, include the following items when accounting for inventory: merchandise or trade stocks. Raw materials. Production in process. Finished products. Supplies that become physically part of an item for sale.

You have to value your inventory at the beginning and end of each tax year to determine your cost of goods sold (line 42 of Schedule C). To determine the value of your inventory, you need a method to identify the items in your inventory as well as a method to value those items. The rules for valuing inventories cannot be the same for all types of businesses. The method you use to value your inventory has to be in accordance with the generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) for similar businesses and it has to clearly reflect revenue. Your inventory management practices have to be consistent from one year to the next.

Under the uniform capitalization rules, you have to capitalize the direct costs and part of the indirect costs of the production or resale activities. Include these costs in the property base you produce or acquire for resale, rather than claiming them as a current deduction. When you use, sell, or otherwise dispose of the goods, you recover the costs by depreciation, amortization, or cost of goods sold.

You may be subject to the uniform capitalization rules if you engage in any of the following activities, unless the goods are produced for use in an activity that is not for business or carried on for profit: You produce real estate or tangible movable property. For these purposes, tangible movable property includes films, sound recordings, video tapes, books, or similar goods. You acquire property to resell it.

These rules do not apply to the following: (1) Taxpayers of small business, defined above under Inventories; (2) Goods that you produce if your indirect costs of producing the goods are $200,000 or less; (3) Goods that you produce if your indirect costs of producing the goods are $200,000 or less; (4) Goods that you produce if your indirect costs of producing the goods are $200,000 or less; (5) Goods that you produce if your indirect costs of producing the goods are $200,000 or less; (6) Goods that you produce if your indirect costs of producing the goods are $200,000 or less; (7) Goods that you produce if your indirect costs of producing the goods are $200,000 or less; (8) Goods that you produce if your indirect costs of producing the goods are $200,000 or less; (9) Goods that you produce if your indirect costs of producing the goods are $200,000 or less; (9) Goods that you produce if your indirect costs of producing the goods are $200,000 or less; (9) Goods that you produce if your indirect costs of producing the goods are $200,000 or less.

There are special accounting methods for certain items of income or expense. They include: Amortization, explained in Chapter 7 of Publication 225. Bad debts, explained under Tax Topic 453, Deduction for bad debts. Exhaustion, explained in Chapter 7 of Publication 225. Depreciation, explained in Publication 946, How To Depreciate Property. Installment Sales, explained in Publication 537. Accounting methods for long-term contracts. See section 460.

If you dispose of business property, you may have a gain or loss to declare on your tax return.However, in some cases, you may have a gain or loss that is not taxable or deductible.This chapter explains whether you actually have a disposal, how to calculate the gain or loss, and where to declare such gain or loss.
For details on damaged, destroyed, or stolen property, see Publication 547, Accidents, Disasters, and Thefts.

Some property exchanges are not taxable. That means that no gain is recognized from the exchange and you cannot deduct any loss. Your gain or loss will not be recognized until you sell or otherwise dispose of the property you receive.

An exchange of property of the same kind is the exchange of one type of property for another of the same type. It is the most common type of non-taxable exchange. In order to constitute an exchange of property of the same type, both the property given and the property received must be both (a) real estate and (b) commercial or investment property.

An installment sale is a sale of goods in which you receive at least one payment after the tax year in which the sale was made has passed. If you provide financing to the buyer of your property, rather than the buyer obtaining a loan or mortgage from a third party, you have likely made an installment sale. For more information about installment sales, see Publication 537.

Generally, the sale of a business is not the sale of a single asset. Instead, all of the assets of the business are sold. Usually, when this occurs, each asset is treated as if it were sold separately for purposes of determining how the gain or loss is to be treated. Both the buyer and seller involved in the sale of the business must declare the allocation of the sale price among the assets of the business to the IRS. Use Form 8594, Asset Acquisition Statement Under Section 1060 to provide this information.

The cost or purchase price of the property usually forms your basis for calculating the gain or loss on its sale or other disposal. However, if you acquired the property as a gift, an inheritance, or in some other way other than by buying it, you must use a basis other than its cost. For more information on the basis, see Publication 551, Basis of Assets.

The adjusted basis of a property is generally its original cost or other basis, plus certain additions and less certain deductions, such as depreciation and casualty losses. When determining profit or loss, the costs of transferring the property to a new owner, such as the selling expenses, are added to the adjusted basis of the property.

Typically, the amount realized from an alienation is the total amount of money that the estate receives plus the fair market value of all the goods or services it receives. The amount it receives also includes any of its obligations that were assumed by the buyer, as well as any obligations to which the property it transferred is subject, such as property taxes or a mortgage.

Fair market value (FMV) is the price at which the goods would have changed hands between a buyer and a seller, without either being forced to buy or sell and both having had reasonable knowledge of all relevant facts.

Your gain or loss obtained from the alienation of property usually constitutes a recognized gain or loss for tax purposes. Recognized gains have to be included in gross income. Recognized losses are deductible from gross income. However, a gain or loss that is obtained from certain types of exchanges of property is not recognized.

You must classify your gains and losses as ordinary or capital gains or losses. You must do this in order to calculate your net capital gain or loss. You will generally have a capital gain or loss if you dispose of a capital asset. Most of the property you own and use for personal or investment purposes is capital property. Certain property you use in your business is not capital property. A gain or loss from the disposal of that property constitutes an ordinary gain or loss. However, if you owned the property for more than 1 year, you may be able to treat the gain or loss as a capital gain or loss. These gains or losses are called gains and losses under section 1231 of the Income Tax Act of 1877. For more information on ordinary and capital gains and losses, see chapters 2 and 3 of the Income Tax Act of 1874 and Publication 544.

If you have a capital gain or loss, you have to determine whether it's a long-term or short-term gain or loss. Whether the gain or loss is long-term or short-term depends on how long you've owned the property before you divest. The length of time you own a property before you divest is called the tenure period.
If you have taxable income, you may also have to use Schedule D (Form 1040).
Use Form 8824 for this purpose.You may also need to use Form 4797 and Schedule D (Form 1040).
Use Form 6252 , Installment Sale Income , and you may also need to use Form 4797 and Schedule D (Form 1040).
Use Form 4684 (accidents and thefts), and you may also need to use Form 4797.
If you are a member of the family of a foreign national, you may be required to pay a fee to the tax authorities for the use of your name.

Your overall business credit for the year consists of your business credits from previous years that can be carried forward to future years plus the total of your current year's business credits.In addition, your current year's overall business credit could be increased later by including business credits from subsequent years applied to previous years.This credit is deducted directly from your taxes.

This credit applies to the cost of any qualified alternative fuel vehicle refuelling property.For more information, see Form 8911.

This credit applies to the costs of starting a pension plan for a new qualified defined benefit or defined contribution plan (including a plan under Section 401 (k)), a SIMPLE plan or a simplified employee pension plan (SEP).For more information, see Publication 560, Retirement Plans for Small Business.

This is a nonrefundable tax credit for a qualifying small business that pays or incurs expenses to provide access to persons with disabilities.You must pay or incur expenses to allow your business to comply with the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA).For more information, see Form 8826.
This credit is available to distillers and importers of distilled spirits, as well as to qualified wholesalers of distilled spirits.For more information, see Form 8906.
This credit applies to wages paid to qualified employees while on family leave and sick leave, subject to certain conditions.For more information, see Form 8994.
You may qualify for this credit if you have employees and operate a business in an empowerment area for which the credit is available.For more information, see Form 8844.
This credit is available to eligible contractors who build certain dwellings that are sold for use as a residence.For more information, see Form 8908.
The investment credit is the sum of the various credits.
This credit generally applies to every low-income qualifying building put into use after 1986 (see Form 8586 for more information).
This credit is for qualified equity investments (capital investments) in qualified Community Development Entities.
This credit applies to qualified expenses incurred in the testing of certain medicines for rare diseases and conditions.For more information, see Form 8820.
These credits are for certain clean vehicles put into service during the tax year.
This credit applies to qualifying railway track maintenance expenses paid or incurred during the tax year.For more information, see Form 8900.
This credit is for the sale of renewable electricity produced in the United States or U.S. territories from qualified energy resources at a qualified facility.For more information, see Form 8835.
This credit provides incentives to businesses to hire people from specific groups who have a particularly high unemployment rate or other special work needs.For more information, see Form 5884.

This credit is for carbon monoxide captured at a qualified facility and disposed of in a secure geological storage facility or used in a qualified project for optimized oil or natural gas recovery.For more information, see Form 8933.

This credit provides businesses with an incentive to continue paying the salary of an employee who is serving on active duty in the uniformed forces (Armed Forces) of the United States for a period of more than 30 days. For more information, see Form 8932.

This credit applies to qualified expenses you paid for childcare for employees' children and qualified expenses you paid for childcare resources and referral services.For more information, see Form 8882.
This credit was designed to motivate businesses to increase the amounts they invest in research and experimentation activities, including energy sources research.For more information, see Form 6765.
This credit applies to the cost of certain health insurance coverage that you provide to certain employees.For more information, see Form 8941.
To claim a general business credit, you must first obtain the forms you need to claim your business credits for the current year.

This chapter primarily explains business income and how to account for it on your tax return, which items are not considered income, and provides guidelines for selected occupations. If there is a connection between any type of income you receive and your business, the income is business income. A connection exists if it is clear that the payment of the income would not have occurred if you did not have the business. You may have business income even if you do not participate in the activity on a regular full-time basis. Income from a job you perform in addition to your regular employment may be business income. For example, you may be in the business of providing services for a ride-sharing business as a second job. Most business income, such as income from the sale of your products or services, is reported on Schedule C. But income from the sale of business assets, such as land and office buildings, is reported on Schedule C. For information on these types of assets, see Chapter 3.

Business income includes amounts you received in your business that were properly reported on Forms 1099-NEC. This includes amounts reported as compensation for people who are not employed in box 1 of the form. You can find more information in the instructions on the back of the Form 1099-NEC you received.

If you have a business, you might receive a Form 1099-K that represents the total dollar amount of your total reportable payment transactions.This may not be the amount you have to report as income, as it may not include all of your entries and may include items that are not included in your entries (such as sales tax).

The income you report on Schedule C could be qualified business income and entitle you to a deduction on line 13 of Form 1040 or 1040-SR. See Form 8995-A or Form 8995 to calculate your deduction, if any.

In your tax return you must declare all income you receive from your business, including income that has not been reported on a Form 1099 filed by the payer, unless excluded by law. In most cases, you will receive your business income in cash, checks, and credit card charges. However, business income may be received in other ways, such as in goods or services. These and other types of income are explained below. If you are a United States citizen with business income from sources outside the United States (foreign income), you must declare that income on your tax return unless it is tax-exempt income under United States laws.

Barter is an exchange of goods or services.You must include in your gross receipts the fair market value of those goods or services you receive in barter at the time you receive them.If you exchange services with another person and they have both agreed in advance on the value of the services, that value will be accepted as the fair market value, unless it can be otherwise demonstrated that the value is different.

If you are a real estate broker who receives income from renting real estate, or you own a hotel, motel, etc., which provides services (cleaning services, etc.) to guests, declare rental income and expenses on Schedule C. If you are not a real estate broker or the type of owner described in the previous sentence, declare rental income and expenses on Schedule E. For more information, see Publication 527, Residential Rental Property.

You are a real estate broker if you engage in the business of selling real estate to clients for the purpose of making a profit from those sales. The rent you receive from the real estate you have for sale to clients is subject to the payment of self-employment tax. However, the rent you receive from real estate you have for speculation or investment purposes is not subject to the payment of self-employment tax.

The rental income from a trailer park is subject to self-employment tax if you are a self-employed trailer park owner who provides lots and facilities to locate the trailer homes as well as substantial services for the convenience of your tenants. You are generally considered to provide substantial services to tenants if these are primarily provided for the convenience of the tenants and are not normally provided to keep the lots in habitable condition. The services are substantial if the remuneration received for the services constitutes a material part of the tenants' rental payments. Examples of services not normally provided for the convenience of the tenants include providing a recreation and leisure centre, delivering a monthly newsletter to tenants, operating a car wash and transport facility to assist tenants in maintaining their homes, and assisting the tenants in the purchase of a car park, which is not a public open space, or the sale of a car park.

Rental income that you receive from the use or occupation of hotels, guesthouses or apartment buildings is subject to self-employment tax if you provide services to the occupants. Generally, you are considered to provide services to the occupants if these are provided primarily for the convenience of the occupants and are not normally provided when it comes to renting rooms only for the occupation of the occupants. An example of a service that is not normally provided for the convenience of a guest is the cleaning service. However, providing heating and lighting, cleaning the stairs and hallways and picking up garbage are services that are normally provided for the convenience of the guests.

Advance payments received under a lease contract which imposes no restrictions on their use or enjoyment constitute income in the year in which you receive them, irrespective of the accounting method or accounting period you use.
A bonus you receive from a landlord for granting a lease is an addition to the rent.
Declare the payments you receive from your lessee for cancelling a lease in your gross receipts for the year in which you received them.

If your tenant makes payments to another person under an agreement to pay his debts or obligations, include those payments in your gross income when the tenant makes the payments. A common example of this type of income is the tenant's payment of property taxes on the leased real estate.

Payments that you receive to settle a lessee's obligation to restore a leased property to its original condition constitute income by the amount by which the payments exceed the adjusted basis of the improvements to the leased property that were destroyed, damaged, removed or disconnected by the lessee.

If you operate a rental business of movable property (equipment, vehicles, formal clothing, etc.), include the amount of rent you receive in your gross receipts in Schedule C. Prepaid rent and other payments described under Rental Property, above, may also be received for renting movable property. If you receive any of those payments, include them in your gross receipts as explained in that section.

Interest received on receivables you have accepted in the regular course of your business transactions constitutes business income. Interest received on loans constitutes business income if you are in the business of lending money.

If a loan owed to you becomes uncollectible during the tax year and you use the accrual method of accounting, you generally have to include in your gross income the accrued qualified stipulated interest accrued up to the time the loan became uncollectible.If the accrued interest you included earlier becomes uncollectible later, you may be able to take a deduction for the uncollectible debt.

If you have shares as a personal investment that is independent of your business activity, dividends on shares are not business income. If you receive dividends from business insurance premiums that you deducted in a prior year, you must declare all or part of your dividends as business income on your income tax return.
The general rule for including cancelled debts in revenue and the exceptions to the general rule is explained below.

Generally, if your debt is cancelled or forgiven, other than a gift or testamentary allowance to you, you must include the cancelled amount in your gross income for tax purposes. Declare the cancelled amount on line 6 of Schedule C if you incurred the debt in your business. If the debt is not a business debt, declare the cancelled amount on line 8c of Schedule 1 (Form 1040).
The following discussion covers some exceptions to the general rule for debt cancellation.
If you have a debt to the seller for goods you bought and the seller reduces the amount you owe, you generally have no income from the reduction.
You do not become a claimant on a cancelled debt to the extent that payment of the debt would have resulted in a deduction.

If a cancelled debt is excluded from income because it arises from a bankruptcy case, the exclusions in situations (2) to (5) do not apply. If the liquidation occurs when you are insolvent, the exclusions in situations (3) and (4) do not apply to the extent that you are insolvent.
For the purposes of this discussion, debt includes any debt for which you are liable or that is tied to property that you own.

You may elect to exclude (up to certain limits) the write-off of qualified commercial real estate debts. If you make this choice, you must reduce the basis of your depreciable real estate by the amount excluded. Make this reduction at the beginning of your tax year following the tax year in which the write-off occurs. However, if you dispose of the property before that date, you must reduce your basis immediately before the disposal.

Restricted assets are assets with certain restrictions that affect their value.If you receive restricted shares or other restricted assets in exchange for services rendered, the fair market value of the assets in excess of their cost is included in your Schedule C income when the restriction is removed.However, you may elect to pay taxes in the year you receive the assets.For more information on the inclusion of restricted assets in income, see Publication 525, Taxable and Nontaxable Income.

In the following situations, you have to recover the depreciation deduction, which means that you will include in your income some or all of the depreciation deduction you made in previous years.

If the commercial use of listed property (explained in Chapter 8 under Depreciation) is reduced to 50% or less during a tax year after the tax year in which you put the property into use, you may have to recover some of the depreciation deduction. You do so by including some of the depreciation you deducted in prior years in income on Schedule C. Use Part IV of Form 4797 to calculate the amount to include on Schedule C. For more information, see What Is the Business-Use Requirement? in Chapter 5 of Publication 946.

If you take a deduction under Section 179 (explained in Chapter 8 under Depreciation) for an asset, and before the end of the asset's recovery period the percentage of business use falls to 50% or less, you must recover part of the deduction under Section 179 by including part of the deduction you took on income in Schedule C. Use Part IV of Form 4797 to calculate the amount to be included in Schedule C. See Chapter 2 of Publication 946 to find out when the deduction is recovered.
If you sell or exchange depreciable property and make a profit, you may have to treat all or part of the gain due to the depreciation as ordinary income.
Do not report on Schedule C any gain or loss on disposal of assets other than commercial stocks or assets held primarily for sale to customers.
