If you reduce or suspend your business activities, use Schedule C to declare any payments you receive for loss of income from your business from insurance or other sources.

You must include in your gross income any compensation you receive during the tax year as a result of any of the following damages related to your business: patent infringement; breach of contract or fiduciary duty; antitrust injury.

You may be entitled to an income deduction if this compensates you for actual economic damage.Your deduction is equal to the lesser of the following amounts:The amount you receive or accumulate for damages during the tax year minus the amount you pay or incur during the tax year to recover that amount.Your loss for the damage you have not yet deducted.

If you receive hidden fees, include them in your income on Schedule C. However, do not include them if you treat them as a reduction in a related expense item, a capital expenditure or the cost of goods sold.

If you recovered a bad debt or any other item deducted in a previous year, include the recovery in income on Schedule C. However, if all or part of the deduction in previous years did not reduce your taxes, you may exclude the part that did not reduce your taxes. If you exclude part of the recovery of income, you must include with your return a calculation showing how you calculated the exclusion.
In some cases, the property or money you receive is not income tax.
Increases in the value of your assets do not constitute income until you earn the increases through sale or other taxable disposal.

If a tenant builds or improves a property, the increase in the value of the property due to the improvements does not constitute income to you; however, if the facts indicate that the improvements constitute rent payment to you, then the increase in value would constitute income.
Borrowing money borrowed through a bona fide loan is not income.
State and local sales taxes levied on consumer goods, which you had to collect and pay to the state or local government, do not constitute income.

Consignments of goods for others to sell for you do not constitute sales. The title to the goods remains with you, the consignor, even after the consignee owns the goods. Therefore, if you ship goods in consignment, you have no profit or loss until the consignee sells the goods. The goods you have shipped in consignment are included in your inventory until they are sold. Do not include in your inventory the goods you receive in consignment. Include your profit or commission on the goods consigned to you in your income when you sell the goods or when you receive your profit or commission, depending on the accounting method you use.

If you enter into a lease after 5 August 1997, you may exclude from your income the construction grant you receive (in cash or as a rent reduction) from your lessor if you receive it under both of the following conditions: Under a short-term lease of commercial premises for the purpose of building or improving qualified long-term real estate for use in your business in that commercial space (store).
You can exclude construction grants to the extent that they do not exceed the amount you spent on construction or improvements.

A short-term lease is a lease (or other agreement of occupation or use) of commercial space for 15 years or less. The following rules apply when determining whether the lease is for 15 years or less: Consider renewal options when calculating whether the lease is for 15 years or less. However, do not consider any renewal option at the fair market value determined at the time of renewal. Two or more successive leases that are part of the same transaction (or a series of related transactions) for the same commercial space or substantially similar commercial space are treated as a single lease.
A commercial premises is a building that you rent, occupy or otherwise use as a tenant in your business of selling tangible movable property or services to the general public.
A qualifying long-term immovable is a non-residential immovable that is part of, or otherwise present in, its commercial space and that reverts to the lessor when the lease terminates.

In general, if you exchange real estate used for business or held for investment purposes only for other real estate used for business or held for investment purposes of a similar type, no gain or loss is recognised.
This section provides information to help you determine whether your income should be reported on Schedule C (Form 1040).

You must declare this income regardless of whether it was declared to you in an information return. You are a direct seller if you meet all of the following conditions: 1. You perform one of the following occupations or businesses: 1. You sell or solicit the sale of consumer products, either in a household or elsewhere than a permanent retail establishment, or to any buyer on a buy-sell basis or on a deposit-fee basis to resell them in a household or other place of business other than a permanent retail establishment. 2. You deliver or distribute newspapers or advertising sales (including any service directly related to that occupation or business). 2. You are a direct seller if you perform substantially all of your (whether paid in cash or not) services described above directly in connection with sales or other production (including the performance of services) in the number of hours worked. 3. Your services are performed on a contract basis other than a federal contract, which is a contract between you and the employee for the purposes of employment, employment, retirement, self-employment, or self-employment, and which is not a contract of employment, employment, self-employment, employment, or self-employment.

If you are a licensed real estate agent or a direct salesperson, your income is reported on Schedule C if the following conditions apply: Substantially all of your pay for services as a real estate agent or direct salesperson is related directly to your sales or other results rather than to the number of hours you work. You perform the services under a written contract that says you will not be treated as an employee for federal tax purposes.

If you are a commodity or call option broker, your gains and losses on transactions or purchases and sales of contracts under Section 1256 (regulated futures contracts, foreign currency contracts, non-equity securities options, equity options of the broker and securities futures contracts of the broker) or property related to those contracts (such as shares used to hedge options) are reported in Annex C. For more information, see Sections 1256 and 1402 (iii).

You are a securities or commodities trader if you engage in the business of buying and selling securities or commodities on your own account. As a securities or commodities trader (even if you made the choice under section 475 (f) of the Securities and Commodities Act) of the adjusted market value, your gain or loss on the sale of securities or commodities is not reported in Schedule C. For more information on securities or commodities traders, see Publication 550, Investment Income and Expenses, and Tax Topic 429, Securities Dealers.
If the fees do not meet the above requirements, please declare them on line 8z of Annex 1 (Form 1040).

If you are a member of a crew who catches fish or other marine life, your income is declared in Annex C if you meet all the requirements set out in Chapter 10 under Member of a crew of a fishing vessel.

Termination payments you receive as a self-employed former insurance agent of an insurance company for services you performed for that company are not reported on Schedule C if all of the following conditions are met: You received payments after you terminated your agreement to perform services for the company; You did not perform any services for the company after you terminated your service agreement and before the end of the year in which you received the payment; You signed an agreement not to compete against the company for at least a period of 1 year from the date you terminated your service agreement; The amount of the payments depended primarily on the policies sold by you or credited to your account during the last year of your service agreement or to the extent that those policies remain in force for some period after your service agreement terminated; or both of these conditions are met; The amount of the payment did not depend on the length of service or the eligibility of the company for the services provided by such policies; or whether the payments were made for the duration of such service or the eligibility of such policies; or whether the company was entitled to receive such payments.
The amount of cash outflows reported in item 1.2.1.1 which is collateralised by assets that are not covered by a master netting agreement and that are not yet pledged to the customer.

This rule applies regardless of whether or not you are guaranteed a minimum amount of earnings, or whether or not you receive credit for unsold newspapers or magazines that you return to your supplier.
The fees you receive for your services as a notary public are declared in Annex C. These payments are not subject to selfemployment tax (see the Instructions for Annex SE (Form 1040)).

Public officials generally do not report what they earn for serving in public office on Schedule C. This rule applies to payments received by an elected tax collector from state funds based on a fixed percentage of taxes collected. Public office includes any elected or appointed office of the United States or its territories, the District of Columbia, a state or its political subdivisions, or an wholly owned subsidiary (instrument) of any such state or local government. Public officials in state or local governments report their fees received from the public on Schedule C if they are paid on a fixed fee basis only and if their services qualify for, but are not covered by, Social Security under a federal-state agreement.

Accounting for your income for income tax purposes sometimes differs from accounting for financial purposes. This section discusses some of the most common differences that can affect business transactions. Calculate your business income based on a tax year and according to your regular accounting method (see Chapter 2). If selling products is a revenue-generating activity in your business, you usually have to use inventories to clearly show your income.
You are liable to tax on all income you earn.

You must use the method chosen each year for all your purchase discounts. If you use the second method, the credit balance in the account at the end of your tax year constitutes business income. Under this method, you do not reduce the cost of goods sold by the cash discounts you received. When valuing your closing (final) inventory, you cannot reduce the invoice price of the goods in stock (available) at the end of the tax year by the average or estimate of discounts received by the goods.

These are reductions from list or catalog prices and are generally not written on the invoice or charged to the customer. Do not write these discounts down in your accounting books. Instead, use only the net amount as the cost of the merchandise purchased.

If the buyer of your property puts part or all of the purchase price in escrow, it does not include any portion of it in gross sales until it is received in effect or implicitly.However, by complying with the terms of the contract and escrow agreement, you will have taxable income, even if you do not accept the money until the next year.

If you receive an insurance or other reimbursement payment for a loss from a mishap or theft, you must subtract it from the loss when calculating your deduction. You cannot deduct the reimbursed portion of a loss from a mishap or theft.

If you produce or purchase goods to sell, you can deduct the cost of goods sold from your gross receipts on Schedule C. However, to determine these costs, you must value your inventory at the beginning and end of each tax year. This chapter applies to you if you are a manufacturer, wholesaler, or retailer (retailer), or if you conduct any business that produces, buys, or sells goods to generate income. This chapter does not apply to a personal service business, such as that of a doctor, lawyer, carpenter, or painter. However, if you work in a personal service business and also sell or charge for materials and supplies that are normally used in your business, this chapter applies to you. There are exceptions for small business taxpayers who might change the cost of goods sold to your business. For information on how to calculate the cost of goods sold, see Chapter 2.

If you are a trader, the initial inventory is the cost of the goods in stock (available) at the beginning of the year and which you will sell to customers.If you are a manufacturer or producer, this includes the total cost of raw materials, production in process, finished products and materials and supplies used in the manufacture of the goods (see Inventories in Chapter 2).In general, the initial inventory will be identical to the closing inventory of the previous year.You must explain any differences in an annex to your declaration.

If you donate inventory (goods you sell during the course of your business), the amount you can claim as a donation deduction is the lesser of the fair market value on the day you donated it or its basis. The basis for the donated inventory is any cost incurred for the inventory in a prior year, which you would otherwise include in your initial inventory for the year of the donation. You must remove the amount of your donation deduction from your initial inventory. It is not part of the cost of goods sold. If the cost of the donated inventory is not included in your initial inventory, the inventory basis is zero, and you cannot claim a charitable donation deduction. Treat the inventory cost the way you would normally treat it according to your accounting method. For example, include the purchase price of the donated inventory and the cost of goods sold in the year of the donation in your initial inventory.

If you are a merchant, use the cost of all the goods you bought for sale.If you are a manufacturer or producer, this includes the cost of all the raw materials or parts purchased to make a finished product.

The difference between the nominal prices of the items and the actual prices you pay for them are called trade discounts. You must use the prices you pay (not the nominal prices) when calculating your purchase costs. Do not show the discount amount separately as a gross revenue item. A car dealership must record the cost of a car in inventory minus any manufacturer's discounts that constitute a trade discount.

Cash discounts are amounts that your suppliers allow you to deduct from your purchase invoices due on time. There are two accounting methods for cash discounts. You can credit them to a separate account for discounts or deduct them from the total of the year's purchases. Regardless of the method you use, it has to be consistent. If you want to change your method for calculating inventory costs, you must file Form 3115. For more information, see Change in Accounting Method in Chapter 2. If you credit cash discounts to a separate account, you must include this credit balance in your business income at the end of the tax year. If you use this method, you will not reduce your cost of goods sold by the amount of cash discounts you owe.

If you withdraw goods for your own or your family's personal use, you must exclude this cost from the total amount of goods purchased for sale. You must do so by crediting the purchase or sales account with the cost of the goods you withdrew for personal use. You must also charge the amount to your advance payment account. An advance payment account is a separate account that you must keep to account for the business income you withdraw to pay for your personal and family expenses. As stated above, you also use it to account for withdrawals of goods for your own or family's use.

Labor costs usually constitute an element of the cost of goods sold only in manufacturing or mining businesses. Small merchants (wholesalers, retailers, etc.) usually do not have labor costs that can be properly allocated to the cost of goods sold. In a manufacturing business, labor costs that can be properly allocated to the cost of goods sold include the direct and indirect labor used to convert raw materials into finished products that can be sold.

Direct labour costs are the wages you pay to employees who spend all their time working directly on the manufacture of products.They also include a portion of the wages you pay to employees who work directly on the products part-time, if you can determine that portion of the wages.

Indirect labour costs are wages you pay to employees who perform general factory functions that have no immediate or direct connection to the manufacture of the product for sale, but which are a necessary part of the manufacturing process.

Other labour costs that cannot be properly charged to the cost of goods sold can be deducted as selling or administrative expenses. Generally, the only types of labour costs that can be properly charged to their cost of goods sold are direct or indirect labour costs, as well as certain other types of costs that are treated as overheads properly charged to the manufacturing process, as explained below under Line 39  Other costs.
Examples of other costs incurred in the manufacturing or mining processes that you charge to your cost of goods sold are as follows.
The cost of packaging and packaging materials which are an integral part of the manufactured product constitute part of its cost of goods sold.
The freight costs of delivery, express delivery and transportation costs of delivering raw materials, supplies you use in production and goods you buy for sale are all part of the cost of goods sold.

General expenses include such expenses as rent, heating, lighting, electricity, insurance, depreciation, taxes, maintenance, labor, and oversight. General expenses you incur as direct and necessary expenses of the manufacturing operation are included in your cost of goods sold.
The amount of lines 35 to 39 is the cost of goods available for sale during the year.

The value of your closing inventory (including, as appropriate, the allowable parts of the cost of raw materials and supplies, direct labour and overheads) is subtracted from line 40.The inventory at the end of the year is also known as closing or ending inventory.Your closing inventory will usually be converted into the inventory at the beginning of the next tax year.
When you subtract your closing inventory (the inventory at the end of the year) from the cost of goods available for sale, what's left over is your cost of goods sold during the tax year.

Calculate your gross profit by first calculating your net income. Calculate your net income in Schedule C (line 3) by subtracting any returns and discounts (line 2) from your gross income (line 1). The returns and discounts include cash or credit refunds you make to customers, discounts and other discounts from the actual purchase price. Then subtract the cost of goods sold (line 4) from your net income (line 3). The result is your gross profit from the business.

You do not have to calculate the cost of goods sold if the sale of goods is not a revenue-generating factor for your business. Your gross profit is equal to your net revenue (gross revenue less any refunds, discounts, or other rebates). Most professions and businesses that sell services instead of products can calculate gross profit directly from net revenue this way.

At the end of each business day, make sure that your records match your actual cash and credit entries for the day.You may find it useful to use cash registers to keep track of entries.You should also use a proper billing system and maintain a separate bank account for your business.

If you collect from the buyer state and local sales taxes that are imposed on you as the seller of goods or services, you must include the amount collected in the gross receipts. If you are required to collect state and local taxes that are imposed on the buyer, and to deliver them to the state or local government, you will not generally include these amounts in the income tax.
If you take items from inventory for your personal use (for yourself, for your family, for gifts, etc.), be sure to remove them from the cost of goods sold.

Inventory forms are available from office supply stores. These forms have columns to record the description, quantity, unit price, and value of each item in the inventory. Each page has space to record who did the physical count, who assigned prices to items, who made the extensions, and who verified the calculations. These forms will help you verify that the total inventory is accurate. They will also provide you with a permanent record to support its validity.

If you operate a retail or wholesale business, you can check the accuracy of your gross profit figure. First, divide the gross profit by the net revenue. The resulting percentage measures the average difference between the cost of goods sold and the selling price of the goods. Then compare that percentage with your profit margin policy. A small difference or nonexistence between these two percentages shows that your gross profit figure is accurate. A large difference between these two percentages could show that you did not calculate sales, purchases, inventories, or other cost items accurately. You must determine the reason for the difference.

You operate a retail business. On average, you add a profit margin to the merchandise so that you will earn 331/3% in gross profit on your sales. The net income (gross income minus returns and discounts) shown on your profit and loss statement is $300,000. Your cost of goods sold is $200,000. This results in a gross profit of $100,000 ($300,000 − $200,000). To check the accuracy of this year's results, you divide the gross income ($100,000) by the net income ($300,000). The resulting percentage of 331/3% confirms your profit margin percentage of 331/3%.

If your business has income from a source other than regular business operations, enter the income on line 6 of Schedule C and add it to gross profit. The result is gross business income. Examples include income from a current account that owes interest, income from the sale of waste (junk income), income from certain credits and refunds of fuel taxes, and amounts recovered from bad debts.

You can deduct the costs of operating your business. These costs are known as business expenses. They are costs that you do not have to capitalize or include in the cost of goods sold, but you can deduct in the current year. To be deductible, a business expense must be both ordinary and necessary. An ordinary expense is one that is common and accepted in the scope of your business. A necessary expense is one that is useful and appropriate to your business. An expense does not have to be indispensable to be considered necessary.

If you are a sole proprietor of a business, you can deduct contributions you make to the plan for yourself on line 16 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040). You can also deduct trustee fees if contributions to the plan do not cover them. Income generated on contributions generally remains tax-free until you or your employees receive individual distributions from the plan. You may also be able to claim a tax credit if you start a new qualified benefits plan or a qualified defined contribution plan (including a 401k plan), a SIMPLE plan, or a SIMPLE. For information on contributions you make to the plan for yourself on line 16 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040), see the IRS Form 5690 (A) for further information on the amount of tax you pay on contributions to the plan and the amount of tax you pay on contributions you make to the plan. For tax-free contributions to the plan, see the IRS Form 5690 (A) for further information on the amount of tax you pay on contributions to the plan and the amount of tax you pay on contributions to the plan.

Rent is any amount you pay for the use of a property that you do not own. Generally, you can deduct rent as a business expense only if the rent is for a property you use in your business. If you have or will have capital invested in the property or will receive title to the property, you cannot deduct rent for that property.

You cannot take a deduction for unreasonable rents. Normally, the issue of reasonableness arises only if you and the landlord are related. The rent paid to a related person is reasonable if it is the same amount that you would pay to a stranger for the use of the same property. The rent is not unreasonable just because it is calculated based on a percentage of gross income. Related persons include your immediate family members, including brothers and sisters (whether of the same parents or brothers and sisters), your spouse, your ancestors, and your lineal descendants.

If you pay the rent in advance, you can deduct only the amount corresponding to your use of the rented property during the tax year. You can deduct the rest of your payment only during the period to which it corresponds.
If you have a deductible, you can deduct other state and local income taxes on Schedule A (Form 1040). Do not deduct federal income taxes.

You can deduct Social Security, Medicare, and federal unemployment (FUTA) taxes you paid as an employer from your own funds. Payroll taxes are briefly explained in Chapter 1. You can also deduct payments you made as an employer to a state unemployment compensation fund or state disability benefit fund.
You can deduct half of your selfemployment taxes from the income tax on line 15 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040).

You can deduct any taxes levied by a state or local government on movable property used in your business on Schedule C. You can also deduct registration fees for the right to use the property within a state or local area.

In Schedule C you can deduct the property taxes you pay for your business property. Deductible property taxes are all state, local, or foreign taxes on real property that are levied for the general welfare of the public. The taxing authority has to tax these taxes uniformly at a similar rate on all properties under its jurisdiction and the income has to be for community or governmental purposes in general.

Treat any sales tax you pay for a service or for the purchase or use of property as part of the cost of the service or property. If the service or cost or use of the property is a deductible business expense, you may deduct the tax as part of that service or cost. If the property is merchandise purchased for resale, the sales tax is part of the cost of the merchandise. If the property is depreciable, add the sales tax to the basis for the depreciation. For more information on the basis of the property, see Publication 551. Do not deduct state and local sales taxes imposed on the buyer that you have to collect and pay to the state or local government. Do not include those taxes in income or gross sales.
If you are a business owner, you may be entitled to a credit or refund for federal excise taxes you pay on fuel used for certain purposes.

Your tax residence is generally your usual place of business, regardless of where you maintain your family residence. It includes the entire city or general area in which your business is located. See Publication 463 for more information.
You can deduct the cost of these and other types of transport between the airport or station and your hotel, or between the hotel and your place of work away from home.
You may deduct the cost of sending luggage and sample or exhibition materials between your usual and temporary workplaces.

You can deduct the cost of operating and maintaining your vehicle while you are traveling away from your home for business purposes.You can deduct the actual expenses or the standard mileage rate (explained above under Car and Truck Expenses), as well as the tolls and parking expenses related to your business.If you rent a car while you are away from your home for business purposes, you can only deduct the portion of the expenses that relate to the business use.
You can deduct the costs of dry cleaning and laundry while you are away on business.

To deduct expenses related to the part of your domicile (home) used for business, you must meet specific requirements. However, your deduction may be limited. To qualify to claim expenses for business use of your domicile, you must meet the following requirements: 1. Your use of the business part of your domicile must be: 1. Exclusive (however, see Exceptions to exclusive use, below), 2. Regular, and 3. Is it used for your business.

To qualify under the exclusive use requirement, you must use a specific area of your home only for your occupation or business. The area used for business may be a room or other separate, identifiable space. The space does not have to be marked by a permanent dividing wall. You do not meet the conditions of the exclusive use requirement if you use the area in question for both business and personal purposes.

To qualify under the regular use requirement, you must use a specific area of your home continuously for business.You do not meet the requirement if your use of the area for business is only occasional or incidental, even if you do not use the area for any other purpose.
If, after taking into account your places of business, your domicile cannot be identified as your principal place of business, you may not deduct the expenses of a home office.
Do not include in item (2) above your deduction of one-half of your self-employment taxes. Use Form 8829, Expenses for Business Use of Your Home, to calculate your deduction.

The IRS provides a simplified method for determining your expenses for the use of your home for business purposes. The simplified method is an alternative to calculating and justifying actual expenses. In most cases, you will calculate your deduction by multiplying $5 by the area of your home used for qualified business use. The area you use to calculate your deduction is limited to 300 square feet.

However, if you choose to use the de minimis safe harbor for tangible goods, you may deduct the de minimis amounts paid to acquire or produce certain tangible goods if these amounts are deducted by you for financial accounting purposes or when keeping your books and records. If you have an applicable financial statement, you may use this safe harbor to deduct amounts paid for tangible goods up to $5,000 per item or invoice. If you do not have an applicable financial statement, you may use the de minimis safe harbor to deduct amounts paid for tangible goods up to $2,500 per item or invoice. Amounts that qualify under this de minimis safe harbor must be included in other expenses such as Part V of Schedule C.
For details on how to make this choice and the requirements for using the de minimis safe harbour for tangible property, see the Tangible Property Regulations.

You may also be able to deduct the following expenses: Advertising. Bank fees. Donations to business organizations. Tuition fees. Work related to an impairment. Concessions for interview expenses. Licenses and regulatory fees. Moving machinery. Helpful services to obtain other work. Penalties and fines you pay for delay in performance or for breach of contract. Repairs and maintenance of real estate or tangible movable property. Refund of income. Supplies and materials. Public services.

Generally, you cannot deduct the following business expenses: Bribery and clandestine commissions. Charitable donations. Demolition expenses or losses. Affiliation fees to business, social, athletic, lunch, sports, airline and hotel clubs. Entertainment expenses. Improvements to real estate or tangible movable property. Improvements are amounts paid for improvements to your property, restorations of your property or work that adapts your property to a new or different use. Lobbying expenses. Penalties and fines you pay to a government agency or agency (instrumentality) because you violated the law. Personal, maintenance or family expenses. Political donations. Settlement agreements or payments related to sexual abuse or sexual harassment if the settlement agreement is subject to a payment of confidentiality or a settlement agreement is not related to the payment of attorneys' fees.

If you use your car or truck for your business, you may be able to deduct the operating and maintenance costs of your vehicle, as well as other local transportation costs and travel far from your home that requires you to stay overnight for business reasons.

Local transportation expenses do not include expenses you incur during trips away from your home that require an overnight stay. Those expenses are deductible as travel expenses and are explained later under Travel and Meals. However, if you use your car during trips away from your home that require an overnight stay, use the rules in this section to calculate the deduction for car expenses. Your tax residence is generally your principal place of business, regardless of where you maintain your family residence. It covers the entire city or general area in which your business or employment is located.
Your place of work can be your domicile if you have an office in your domicile which meets the requirements for being a principal place of business.

The standard mileage rate for 2024 is 67 cents per mile. If you choose to use the standard mileage rate for one year, you cannot deduct your actual car expenses in that year except for parking and toll charges that are related to your business.

You may not have used the standard mileage rate if: 1. you operate five or more cars at a time; 2. you claimed an depreciation deduction for the car using a method other than the uniform (constant) depreciation method, e.g., ACRS (Accelerated Cost Recovery System) or MACRS (Modified Cost Recovery System); 3. you claimed a deduction on the car under section 179; 4. you claimed the special depreciation allowance on the car; 5. you claimed the actual expenses of a leased car; or 6. you are a rural postman who has received a qualified refund.

In addition to using the standard mileage rate, you can deduct all parking and toll charges that are related to your business. (The parking charges you pay for parking the car at your place of work are non-deductible commuting expenses.)

If you purchase goods for use in your business that are expected to last more than 1 year, you generally cannot deduct the entire cost as a business expense in the year you purchase them. You must distribute the cost over 1 tax year and deduct part of the cost each year on Schedule C. This method of deducting the cost of commercial goods is called depreciation. The explanation given here is brief.

You can depreciate goods if they meet all of the following requirements: It must be property that you own. It must be used in the business or held to produce income. You can never depreciate inventory (explained in chapter 2) because you don't have it for use in your business. It must have a useful life that extends substantially beyond the year it is put into service. It must have a determinable useful life, meaning it must be something that wears out, deteriorates, depletes, becomes obsolete, or loses its value from natural causes. You can never depreciate the cost of land because the land does not wear out, becomes obsolete, or is depleted. It cannot be exempt property. This includes property put into use and disposed of in the same year.

Instead, you deduct these amounts on line 21 of Schedule C. Improvements are amounts paid for improvements to your property, restorations to your property, or work that adapts your property to a new or different use.

You may make a choice to treat certain repairs or replacements in your occupation or business as depreciation-subject improvements.This choice is available if you treat these amounts as capital expenditures in your books and records used regularly to calculate your income and expenses.

The maximum amount you can choose to deduct during 2024 is generally $1,220,000 (higher limits apply to certain goods). This limit is generally reduced by the amount by which the cost of the property put into use during the tax year exceeds $3,050,000. The total amount of depreciation (including the deduction under section 179) you can take for a passenger car that you use in your business and that was first put into use in 2024 is $12,400 ($20,400 if the special depreciation allowance for qualified passenger cars put into use in 2024).

Use Form 4562,Depreciation and Amortization, if you claim any of the following items: Depreciation of property put into use during the current tax year. A deduction under section 179. Depreciation of any listed property (regardless of when it was put into use).
You cannot deduct your own salary or any income you make from your business for personal purposes.

Some of the ways by which you can pay your employees are listed below: Premiums. Bonuses. Tuition fees. Marginal benefits (explained later). Loans or advances that you do not expect employees to pay back if they are for personal services that have actually been rendered. Assets that you transfer to an employee as payment for services rendered. Reimbursements of employees' business expenses.

For example, if you allow an employee to use a car or other property that you lease, you deduct the cost of the lease as a rental or leasing expense. If you own the property, include your deduction for its cost or other basis as a Section 179 deduction or an impairment deduction. You may be able to exclude all or part of the marginal benefits you provide from your employees' wages. For more information on marginal benefits and the exclusion of benefits, see Publication 15-B.

You can generally deduct premiums you pay for the following types of insurance related to your business: 1. fire, theft, flood, or similar insurance. 2. credit insurance that covers losses for business bad debts. 3. group hospital and medical insurance for employees, including long-term care insurance. 4. liability insurance. 5. professional negligence insurance that covers your personal liability for professional negligence resulting in injury or damage to patients or customers. 6. workers' compensation insurance for accidents at work established by law that covers any claims for physical injuries or work-related illnesses suffered by employees in your business, regardless of liability. 7. contributions to the state unemployment insurance fund are tax deductible as if they were considered taxes under state law. 8. general insurance that covers general business expenses that cover incapacity and disability for employees, including long-term care insurance. 10. insurance against accidents at work established by law that covers any claims for physical injuries or work-related illnesses suffered by employees in your business, regardless of liability.

You cannot deduct premiums from a policy that pays for loss of income due to illness or disability. However, see item (8) of the list above. 3. Certain life insurance policies and annuities. 1. For contracts issued before June 9, 1997, you cannot deduct premiums from a life insurance policy that benefits you, an employee, or any other person who has a financial interest in your business if you are the direct beneficiary of the policy. However, your actual losses may also be deductible.
You may be able to deduct the amount you pay for health insurance, dental insurance and qualified long-term care insurance for you and your family.

See Form 8962, Premium Tax Credit (PTC), and its separate instructions and use Publication 974 if the insurance plan established, or deemed established, under your business was obtained through the Health Insurance Marketplace and you are claiming the premium tax credit.

You cannot deduct the expenses in advance, even if you pay them in advance.This rule applies to any expenses paid in sufficient advance to, in effect, create an asset with a useful life that extends substantially beyond the end of the current tax year.

Some taxpayers are required to limit the deduction of expenses for interest on their business. See the Instructions for Form 8990 to determine if you are required to limit the deduction of expenses for interest on your business, who is required to file Form 8990 and how certain businesses may choose not to be subject to the limitation of expenses for interest on business. You cannot use Schedule C to deduct the interest you pay on personal loans. If a loan is part business and part personal, you must divide the interest between the personal and the business portion.

The following are some additional points you should consider: How to allocate interest between personal use and business use; Commercial interest limitation; When to deduct interest; Rules for a loan with an interest rate below the market rate (this is generally a loan for which no interest is charged or for which interest is charged at a rate below the applicable federal rate).

Legal and professional fees, such as fees charged by accountants, which are ordinary and necessary expenses directly related to the operation of your business are deducted on Schedule C. However, you cannot normally deduct legal fees you pay to acquire business assets. Add them to your property basis. If the fees include payments for work of a personal nature (such as drafting a will), you can take a business deduction only for the portion of the fee related to your business.

In Schedule C you can deduct the cost of preparing the part of your tax return that relates to your business as a sole proprietor of a business or as a statutory employee.In Schedule C you can also deduct the amount you pay or incur to resolve certain tax deficiencies related to your business as a sole proprietor of a business or as a statutory employee.

A nonresident alien (and certain resident aliens) of a country with which the United States has an income tax treaty may be eligible for certain benefits. Most treaties require the nonresident alien to be a resident of the treaty country in order to qualify in the year in which the benefit is claimed. However, in the case of certain students, apprentices, teachers, or researchers, some treaties only require the nonresident alien to be a resident of the treaty country immediately prior to arriving in the United States.

You can access the tax treaty tables at IRS.gov/TreatyTables. In addition, you can access the text of newly signed U.S. income tax treaties, protocols, and tax information exchange agreements (TIEA) and the technical explanations of the Treasury Department tax treaties that accompany them as soon as they are available to the public, as well as the U.S. Model Income Tax Convention at Home.Treasury.gov/Policy-Issues/Tax-Policy/International-Tax. Please note that treaty and TIEA documents are available on that web page after they are signed and prior to their ratification and entry into force. The full text of the treaties is also available at IRS.gov/Businesses/International-States/United States-Businesses-International-Tax-Relationships/International-Tax-Relationships. For more information about tax treaties, you can read the IRS's General Tax Requirements and Benefits for Taxpayers/Right to Re-Income/Tax Benefits.

Treaty-subject income of a nonresident alien is gross income for which tax is limited by a tax treaty. Treaty-subject income includes, for example, dividends from sources within the United States that are taxed at a treaty-subject rate not exceeding 15%. Treaty-subject income is the gross income of a nonresident alien for which tax is not limited by a tax treaty. To determine treaty-subject income tax, calculate the tax for each separate income tax item subject to the reduced rate that applies to that item under the tax treaty. To determine treaty-subject income tax, calculate the tax at either the 30% or the gradual rate, depending on whether the income is not directly related to the business or occupation, but if the income is not taxed as taxable income, the taxable income is not taxed as the highest taxable income in the United States.

The following paragraphs briefly explain the exemptions that are available under tax treaties for income from personal services, remittances, scholarships, career development grants, and capital gains income. The conditions for claiming the exemptions vary under each tax treaty. For more information on the conditions under a particular tax treaty, download the full text of most tax treaties with the United States at IRS.gov/Businesses/International-Businesses/United-States-Income-Tax-Treaties-A-to-Z. Technical explanations for many of those treaties are also available on that website. See also Publication 901. The benefits of tax treaties also cover income such as dividends, interest, royalties, pensions, and annuities. These types of income might be exempt from U.S. taxation or subject to a reduced taxation rate. For more information, see the IRS's tax treaty file.

Under most income tax treaties, non-resident aliens from treaty countries and dual resident aliens who by the tie rule break the treaty treaty treaty rule in favor of the treaty country (see Chapter 1), who are temporarily present in the United States to perform services, may be eligible to exempt some or all personal service income from U.S. taxes if they meet the requirements of the relevant treaty article.
Some income tax treaties contain different requirements, such as a different maximum period of presence.For more information, see Publication 901.

Some income tax treaties contain an article on "independent personal services", which allows residents of a treaty country to exempt income earned as an independent contractor or as a self-employed person from U.S. taxes if they are present in the United States for a period not exceeding a certain number of days and if they do not have a regularly available fixed income base in the United States.

Under many income tax treaties, teachers or professors who are nonresident aliens and who temporarily visit the United States for the primary purpose of teaching at an accredited university or other educational institution are not subject to U.S. income tax on compensation received for teaching for the first 2 or 3 years after arrival in the United States. Many treaties also provide an exemption for participating in research. Typically, the teacher or professor has to be in the United States primarily to teach, lecture, instruct, or participate in research. A substantial portion of that person's time has to be devoted to those tasks.

Under some tax treaties, students, apprentices, and interns are exempt from tax on remittances received from abroad for tuition and living expenses. Additionally, under some treaties, scholarships and grants to conduct research, and a limited amount of compensation received by students, apprentices, and interns, may be exempt from tax. If you came to the United States as a nonresident alien, but are now a resident alien, the treaty exemption may still apply. See Students, Apprentices, Practitioners, Teachers, Professors, and Researchers Who Became Resident Aliens, below, Resident Aliens.
Most treaties provide for the exemption of gains from the sale or exchange of movable property.
The tax treaty benefits may be available to resident aliens in the following situations.

Resident aliens generally do not qualify for the benefits of tax treaties, because most tax treaties contain a 1640 Exemption Clause that preserves or protects the right of the United States to tax its citizens and residents as if the tax treaty had not been put into effect. However, many tax treaties have exceptions to the Exemption Clause, which could allow a resident alien to continue to claim treaty benefits. Some exceptions to the Exemption Clause apply to all resident aliens (for example, under the treaty between the United States and the People's Republic of China); others apply only to permanent resident aliens who are not legal residents of the United States (such as green card holders).

The tax treaty with Canada and Germany states that if a resident of the United States receives Canadian or German social security benefits, those benefits are treated for U.S. income tax purposes as if they were received under U.S. Social Security law. If you receive Canadian or German social security benefits, you should note them on line 1 of your Social Security Benefits Worksheet in the Instructions for Form 1040 for purposes of determining the taxable amount you must report on line 6b of Form 1040 or 1040-SR. You are not required to file a Form 8833 for those benefits.

However, if you entered the United States as a nonresident alien, but are now a resident alien for U.S. tax purposes, the treaty exemption will still apply if the treaty safeguard clause (explained above) provides you with an exception and otherwise you meet the requirements for the treaty exemption (including any limitations for scholarships, grants and professional development grants, and for wages or other compensation for personal services). If you become a resident alien, you generally can no longer claim a treaty tax exemption for this income. However, if you entered the United States as a nonresident alien, but are now a resident alien for U.S. tax purposes, the treaty exemption will still apply if the treaty safeguard clause (explained above) provides you with an exception and you otherwise meet the requirements for the treaty exemption (including any limitations for scholarships, grants and professional development grants, and for wages or other compensation for personal services). If you are not a resident alien, you may avoid the treaty exemption by submitting your income tax return to the taxpayer, even if it is not required by the treaty, as further explained in your tax return to your taxpayer, as a resident alien's tax return, as described in your Form W-9.

In certain cases, you do not need to declare income on your Form 1040 or 1040-SR because the income will be exempt from U.S. taxes under a treaty. However, if the income has been reported as taxable income on a Form W-2, Form 1042-S, Form 1099, or other information form, you must declare it on the appropriate line of Form 1040 or 1040-SR (for example, line 1a, the amounts declared in box 1 of Form W-2).

If you claim treaty benefits that invalidate or modify any provision of the Internal Revenue Code and, in claiming these benefits, your tax is reduced, or could be reduced, you must attach a duly completed Form 8833 to your tax return.
These are the most common situations for which a Form 8833 is required.For additional provisions, see the instructions on Form 8833.

You do not have to file Form 8833 for any of the following situations: 1. Claim a reduced rate under a treaty for the withholding of tax on interest, dividends, rents, royalties, or other fixed or determinable income paid annually or periodically normally subject to the 30% rate. 2. Claim that a treaty reduces or modifies taxation on income from service (s) of staff; dependents; pensions; annuities; social security and other public pensions; or income from artists, athletes, students, apprentices, or teachers. This includes scholarships for studies and professional development. 3. Claim a reduced or modified income tax under a treaty for the withholding of tax on interest, dividends, rents, royalties, or other fixed or determinable income normally subject to the 30% rate. 2. Claim that a treaty reduces or modifies taxation on income from service (s) of staff; dependents; pensions; annuities; social security and other public pensions; or income from artists, athletes, students, apprentices, or teachers. This includes scholarships for studies and professional development. 3. Claim a reduced or modified income taxation under a treaty for income from any State under an International Social Security Agreement or an international social security agreement or a diplomatic or consularly agreement. 4. Claim that a treaty reduces or modifies taxation on income from a treaty for interest on interest, dividends taxation, or taxation, or taxation, or taxation, or taxation, or taxation, or taxation, or taxation, or taxation, or taxation, or taxation, or taxation, or taxation, or taxation.
If you are required to declare treaty benefits but fail to do so, you could be subject to a $1,000 fine for each violation.

Employees of an international organization might be able to exempt their salaries pursuant to a provision, if any, in the international agreement creating such international organization, or upon meeting the requirements for obtaining an exemption for those salaries under U.S. tax law. An "international organization" is an organization designated by the President of the United States through an Executive Order to qualify for the privileges, exemptions, and immunities provided in the International Organizations Immunities Act. The exemption explained in this chapter applies only to pay received for official services performed for a foreign government or organization. Other income from U.S. sources received by persons who qualify for this exemption might be fully taxable or might be given favorable treatment pursuant to a provision of a tax treaty that applies to such an organization. The proper treatment of such income (i.e., dividends, etc.) is explained in this publication.

First, you must check the tax exemption provisions under the Vienna Conventions or a bilateral consular convention, if any, to see if your salaries qualify for the exemption from U.S. income taxes under those provisions.In general, you are not entitled to the tax exemption available under the Vienna Conventions or a bilateral consular convention if you are a U.S. citizen or a resident alien of the United States.For more information on the Vienna Conventions and bilateral consular conventions, please email the Department of State's Office of Foreign Missions at OFMAssistants@state.gov.uk.

If you are a U.S. citizen or resident alien who works in the United States for a foreign government, your wages are not normally exempt. For more information, see Wages and Pensions Paid by a Foreign Government in Publication 901.

Employees of a foreign government who do not qualify under the tax exemption provisions of the Vienna Conventions, a bilateral consular convention, or a tax treaty may be able to exempt their foreign government salaries from U.S. income tax if they meet the following requirements to obtain an exemption for such salaries under U.S. tax law. The exemption under U.S. tax law applies only to current employees of a foreign government and not to ex-employees. Pensions received by ex-employees of a foreign government living in the United States do not qualify for the exemption explained here. This exemption does not apply to independent contractors. The common law rules apply to determine whether you are an employee or an independent contractor. See Publication 1779 and Publication 15-A. Your wages are not repaid to the foreign government for income tax if you meet the following requirements to obtain an exemption for such salaries under U.S. tax law. The exemption under U.S. tax law applies only to current employees of a foreign government and not to ex-employees of a foreign government living in the United States. Pensions received by ex-employees of a foreign government living in the United States do not qualify for the exemption explained here. This exemption does not apply to independent contractors. The common law rules apply to determining whether you are an employee or an independent contractor. See Publication 1779 and Publication 15-A.

However, see Foreign Nationals who maintain their immigrant (legal permanent resident) status. "), below, for a special rule that may affect your eligibility for this exemption. To claim the tax exemption, you must be able to show that you meet both requirements of U.S. tax law.

If you are a U.S. citizen, you must provide proof of residency in the United States, and if you are a U.S. citizen, you must provide proof of residency in the United States. If you are a U.S. citizen, you must provide proof of residency in the United States. If you are a U.S. citizen, you must provide proof of residency in the United States.

Many agreements establishing international organizations contain a provision that may exempt your wages from U.S. income tax. If you are employed by an international organization in the United States, first determine whether the international agreement establishing the international organization for which you work has such a provision and whether you qualify for the exemption under it. These provisions generally do not exempt wages of employees who are U.S. citizens and resident aliens.

If the international agreement by which the international organization you work for is created does not contain a provision for tax exemption and you are not a U.S. citizen (or if you are a U.S. citizen and also a citizen of the Republic of the Philippines), you may be able to exempt your wages under U.S. tax law. However, see Aliens who maintain their immigrant (lawful permanent resident) status. "), below, for a special rule that may affect your eligibility for this exemption. This exemption under U.S. tax law applies only to current employees of international organizations and not to former employees. Pensions received by ex-employees of international organizations living in the United States do not qualify for the exemption explained here. This exemption does not apply to independent contractors. Common law rules apply to determine whether you are an employee or an independent contractor.

If you sign the waiver provided by section 247 (b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (USCIS Form I-508) to maintain your lawful permanent resident status (known as a green card), you no longer qualify for tax exemption under U.S. tax law as of the date of filing the waiver. If you are an employee of a foreign government or an international organization who has a "green card", in order to claim exemption under U.S. tax law you must also be able to demonstrate with written evidence from USCIS that you have not signed or filed a USCIS Form I-508.

Before departing the United States, all aliens (except those listed under Aliens Who Do Not Need to Obtain Sailing or Departure Permits, below) must obtain a certificate of compliance. This document, commonly known as the "sailing permit" or "departure permit", is part of the income tax form you must file before departing. You will receive a sailing or departure permit after filing a Form 1040-C or Form 2063.

If you fall into any of the following categories, you do not have to obtain a navigation or departure permit before leaving the United States.If you fall into any of these categories and do not have to obtain a navigation or departure permit, you must be able to substantiate your claim for exemption with appropriate identification or provide the authority granting the exemption.

If you are an alien who falls into the category (1a) or (2b) above, and who filed for waiver under section 247 (b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act, you must obtain a navigation or departure permit.This is true even if your income is exempt from U.S. taxation due to an income tax treaty, consular agreement, or international agreement.

Foreign students, industrial apprentices, and exchange visitors, including their spouses and children, who enter only on an F-1, F-2, H-3, H-4, J-1, J-2, or Q visa and who do not receive income from U.S. sources while in the United States on those visas, except: Grants to cover expenses related to study or training in the United States, such as travel, living, and tuition expenses; The value of any service or food and lodging related to such study or training; USCIS-authorized employment income; or Interest income on deposits that is not directly related to a U.S. occupation or business (see Interest income in Chapter 3).

Foreign students, including their spouses and children, who enter only on an M-1 or M-2 visa and who do not receive income from U.S. sources while in the United States on those visas, except: USCIS-authorized employment income or interest income on deposits that is not directly related to a U.S. occupation or business (see Interest income in chapter 3).

Certain other aliens who are temporarily in the United States who have not received taxable income during the tax year up to and including the departure date or during the prior tax year. If the IRS has reason to believe that an alien has received taxable income and departure jeopardizes the collection of income tax, then it may require the alien to obtain a navigation or departure permit. Aliens in this category are: 1. Foreign military apprentices who enter the United States for the purpose of training under the sponsorship of the Department of Defense and who depart the United States with official military travel orders; 2. Foreign business visitors on a B-1 visa, or on both B-1 and B-2 visas, who do not remain in the United States or in any U.S. territory for more than 90 days during the tax year; 3. Foreign visitors with a B-2 visa; 4. Foreigners who cross the border with a U.S. visa for business or pleasure; or 5. Foreigners who are not required to be on a U.S. visa for any purpose, such as a business card or a travel document; or those who are not covered by a U.S. visa for travel to the territory for more than 90 days during the year; or who are not covered by a U.S. visa for travel to the territory for tax purposes of the year; or for which the visa is issued.
Foreign nationals who are residents of Canada or Mexico and who frequently travel between that country and the United States for work, and whose wages are subject to U.S. withholding taxes.

If you do not fit into any of the categories listed above under Aliens Who Do Not Need to Obtain Shipping or Departure Permits, you must obtain a shipping or departure permit. To obtain a permit, file Form 1040-C or Form 2063 (whichever is applicable) with your local TAC office before leaving the United States. See Forms You Must File, below. You must also pay all taxes shown as due on Form 1040-C and any taxes due for prior years. See How to Pay Taxes and Get Refunds, below.

To obtain a certificate of compliance, you must go to a TAC office at least 2 weeks before you leave the United States and file either Form 2063 or Form 1040-C and any other required tax returns that have not been filed. The certificate cannot be issued more than 30 days before you leave the United States. If both you and your spouse are foreign nationals and both of you are leaving the United States, you must both go to the TAC office.

The process for obtaining your navigation or exit permit will be speeded up if you bring to the TAC office the documents and papers related to your income and your stay in the United States. Bring the following records with you if they apply: 1. Your passport and alien registration card or visa. 2. Copies of your U.S. income tax returns filed for the past 2 years. If you have been in the United States for less than 2 years, bring the income tax returns you filed for that period. 3. Receipts for income taxes you paid on those returns. 4. Exit receipts, bank records, canceled checks and other documents proving your deductions, business expenses and dependents you claimed on your returns. 5. A written statement from each employee showing the wages paid and the current professional income tax from January 1st until the day of the current tax year if they apply. 9. A copy of your U.S. income tax returns filed for the last 2 years. If you were in the United States for less than 2 years, bring the income tax returns you filed for that period. 3. Receipts for income taxes you paid on those returns. 4. Bank records, canceled checks and other documents proving your deductions, business expenses and dependents you claimed on your returns. 5. A written statement from each employee showing the wages paid and the current salary and the current salary from January 1st until the day of the current tax year if they apply. 9.

If you are required to obtain a navigation or departure permit, you must file Form 2063 or Form 1040-C. Both forms have a section titled  certificate of compliance . When the certificate of compliance is signed by an agent of the Area Director of the Taxpayer Assistance Center, it certifies that your U.S. tax obligations are in compliance with the information available to you. Your copy of the signed certificate of Form 1040-C, or the unsigned certificate of Form 2063, is your navigation or departure permit.

Foreign nationals in any of these categories, who have not filed an income tax return or paid income tax in any tax year, must file the income tax return and pay income tax before they can be issued a navigation or departure permit on Form 2063.The navigation or departure permit that is detached from Form 2063 may be used for all departures in the current year.However, the IRS may cancel the navigation or departure permit for any subsequent departure if it believes that the collection of income tax for that subsequent departure is at risk.

If you must obtain a navigation or departure permit and do not qualify to file Form 2063, you must file Form 1040-C. Generally, any income received or reasonably expected to be received during the tax year up to and including the departure date must be reported on Form 1040-C and the tax shown as due on it must be paid. When you pay any taxes due as shown on Form 1040-C, present all returns, and pay all taxes due for prior years, you will receive a navigation or departure permit. However, the IRS may allow you to provide a bond that guarantees payment instead of paying taxes for certain years.

If you provide the IRS with information that shows, to the IRS's satisfaction, that you intend to return to the United States and that your departure does not put your income tax collection at risk, you may obtain a sailing or departure permit by filing Form 1040-C without having to pay the tax it shows. However, you must file all income tax returns that you have not yet filed as required and pay all income tax due on those returns. Your Form 1040-C must include all income received, and income reasonably expected to be received, during the entire departure year. The sailing or departure permit issued with this Form 1040-C may be used for all departures during the current year. However, the IRS may cancel the sailing or departure permit for any subsequent payment of income tax if it appears that the income tax liability is incurred.

If the spouse is in the process of leaving and is a nonresident alien, they cannot file joint returns; however, if both spouses are resident aliens, they can file a joint return on Form 1040-C if: it can be reasonably expected that both spouses will qualify to file a joint return at the normal close of their tax year and the tax year of both spouses ends at the same time.

You must pay all of the tax that is shown as due on Form 1040-C at the time of filing, except when you provide a bond or the IRS is satisfied that your departure will not jeopardize the collection of income tax. You must also pay any taxes due for prior years. If the tax calculation on Form 1040-C results in an overpayment, there is no tax to pay at the time of filing your return. However, the IRS cannot provide a refund at the time of departure. If you are owed a refund, you must file Form 1040-NR at the end of the tax year.

If you pay all taxes owed from previous years, you may provide a bond that guarantees payment in lieu of paying the income tax shown on your Form 1040-C or the tax return for the previous year if the period for filing that return has not expired.

Form 1040-C is not an annual U.S. income tax return. If an income tax return is required by law, that return must be filed even if a Form 1040-C has already been filed. Chapters 5 and 7 explain filing the annual U.S. income tax return. The tax paid with Form 1040-C should be taken as a credit against the tax liability for the full tax year on your annual U.S. income tax return.
