You must first determine whether, for income tax purposes, you are a nonresident alien or a resident alien.If you are both a nonresident and a resident alien in the same year, then you have a dual residence.See Aliens with Dual Residence, below.See also Nonresident Spouse Treated as a Resident and some other special situations discussed in this chapter.

You are a U.S. resident alien for tax purposes if you meet the green card requirement or the substantial presence requirement for the calendar year 2024 (January 1 to December 31), and you may be eligible to be treated as a resident of the United States for part of the year even if you do not meet either requirement.

You are a resident for tax purposes if you are a lawful permanent resident of the United States at any time during the calendar year 2024. (However, see Aliens with Dual Residency, below.) This is known as the green card requirement. You are a lawful permanent resident of the United States at any time if you have been given the privilege, under United States immigration laws, to permanently reside in the United States as an immigrant. You generally have this immigration status if the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) (or its predecessor organization) has issued you a Form I-551, Permanent Resident Card, also known as a green card.

If you are a resident of the United States, you are considered to have your status terminated if the United States government issues a final administrative or judicial order of exclusion or deportation.

When you make the filing by mail, you must send your return by registered mail, requesting the acknowledgement of receipt (or a foreign equivalent), and retain a copy and a receipt indicating that it was sent and received. Until you have a receipt that your letter was received, you are still a foreign resident for tax purposes, even if the USCIS did not recognize the validity of your green card because it is older than 10 years or because you have been absent from the United States for a period of time. If the USCIS or a United States consular officer initiates this determination, your resident status will be considered abandoned when the final administrative abandonment order is issued. If you are granted an appeal to a federal court of competent jurisdiction, a final court order is required. Under United States immigration law, a lawful permanent resident who is required to file a return of tax and is not required to file a return of tax may be considered a permanent resident for tax purposes, even if the green card is not recognized by the USCIS because it is older than 10 years or because you have been absent from the United States for a period of time.

You are a resident for tax purposes if you meet the substantial presence requirement for calendar year 2024, which is that you must be physically present in the United States for at least: 1. 31 days in 2024 and 2. 183 days during the 3-year period including the years 2024, 2023 and 2022, counting: 1. all days you were present in 2024, 2. 1/3 of the days you were present in 2023 and 3. 1/6 of the days you were present in 2022.

When calculating days of presence in the United States, you may exclude only the days on which you actually competed in a sporting event. You may not exclude days on which you were in the United States to practice for the event, perform promotional or other event-related activities, or to travel between events. If you qualify to exclude days of presence as a professional athlete, you must file a fully completed Form 8843 with the IRS.

Why you should file Form 8843 with your IRS if you are not required to file a return, send Form 8843 to the following address: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Center Austin, TX 73301-0215 You must file Form 8843 before the due date for Form 1040-NR. The due date for filing the return is explained in Chapter 7. If you are required to file Form 8843 and fail to file it on time, you cannot exclude the days you were present in the United States as a professional athlete or because of a medical condition that arose while you were in the United States. This does not apply if you can demonstrate by clear and convincing evidence that you took reasonable steps to become aware of the filing requirements for a return and the important steps to meet those requirements.

f. you are not in the United States for less than 24 hours and are in transit between two places outside the United States. f. you are considered to be in transit if you are engaged in activities that are substantially related to completing the trip to your foreign destination. e.g. if you are traveling between airports in the United States to change planes en route to your foreign destination, you are considered to be in transit. f. however, you are not considered to be in transit if you attend a business meeting during your stay in the United States. e.g. this is true even if the meeting takes place at the airport.

Do not count days when you are temporarily present in the United States as a regular crew member of a foreign ship (ship or craft) engaged in transportation between the United States and a foreign country or territory of the United States.

For example, you may be able to prove that you had or did not intend to leave if your purpose of visiting the United States could be fulfilled for a period that was not long enough to qualify you for the substantial presence test. However, if you need an extended period of time to fulfill the purpose of your visit and that period would qualify you for the substantial presence requirement, you cannot establish your intention to leave the United States before the end of that extended period. In the case of a person who is deemed mentally incompetent, proof of intent to leave the United States may be determined by completing a pattern of behavior that the incompetent person had before arriving in the United States and determining whether the pattern of behavior was complete before the incompetent person arrived in the United States. If you were unable to submit a Form 8843 to the IRS for treatment for more than one day after arrival, but were unable to complete the entire period of time before you arrived in the United States due to a medical condition that made your stay unqualified, you may be excluded from further treatment by filing Form 8843 V.

A foreign governmental individual is a person (or an individual's immediate family member) who is temporarily present in the United States either as a full-time employee of an international organization, on account of his or her diplomatic status, or on account of a visa (other than a visa granting lawful permanent residence) that the Secretary of the Treasury determines represents a diplomatic or consular state on a full-time basis.

If you are present in the United States on an A-3 or G-5 visa as a personal employee, assistant, or domestic worker for a foreign government or an official of an international organization, you are not considered an individual related to the foreign government and must count your days of presence in the United States for purposes of the substantial presence requirement.

A foreign employer is a U.S. entity with an office or establishment in a foreign country or U.S. territory. If you qualify to exclude days of attendance as a teacher or apprentice, you must file a fully completed Form 8843 with the IRS. See Form 8843 below.
If you qualify for exclusion from student holidays, you must file a fully completed Form 8843 with the IRS. See Form 8843 below.

Even if you meet the substantial presence requirement, you may still be treated as a nonresident alien if you: are present in the United States for less than 183 days during the year, maintain a tax residence in a foreign country during the year, and have a closer connection during the year to a foreign country in which you have a tax residence than to the United States (or to the United States (unless you have a closer connection to two foreign countries, as explained below).

You can show that you have a closer connection to two foreign countries (but not more than two) if you meet all of the conditions below: You maintained a tax domicile as of the first day of the year in a foreign country; You changed your tax domicile during the year to a second foreign country; You continued to maintain your tax domicile in the second foreign country for the remainder of the year; You had a closer connection to each foreign country than to the United States during the period in which you maintained a tax domicile in that foreign country; You are subject to taxation as a resident under the tax laws of either of the two foreign countries for the entire year; or You are subject to taxation as a resident in both foreign countries during the period in which you maintained a tax domicile in each foreign country.

Your tax domicile is the general area of your principal place of business, employment or workplace, regardless of where you maintain your household. Your tax domicile is the place where you work permanently or indefinitely as an employee or as a self-employed person. If you do not have a regular or principal place of work due to the nature of your work, then your tax domicile is the place where you live regularly. If you are not in any of these categories, you are considered to be an itinerant and your tax domicile is wherever you work. To determine whether you have a closer connection with a foreign country, your tax domicile must also exist throughout the current year and must be located in the same foreign country with which you claim to have a closer connection.

For purposes of determining whether it has a closer connection with a foreign country, the term "foreign country" means: Any territory under the sovereignty of the United Nations or a government other than the United States; The territorial waters of the foreign country (as determined under U.S. law); The seabed and subsoil of the submarine zones adjacent to the territorial waters of the foreign country and over which the foreign country has exclusive rights under international law to explore and exploit natural resources and U.S. territories.

It does not matter whether your permanent home is a rented apartment, a rented apartment or a furnished room, or whether you rent or own it, but it is important that your home is available at all times, on a continuous basis and not just for short stays.

Steps to change your immigration status to permanent resident include, but are not limited to, filing the following forms: Form I-508, Waiver of Certain Rights, Privileges, Exemptions, and Immunities; Form I-485, Application to Register Permanent Residence or Adjust Status; Form I-130, Petition for Alien Relative; Form I-140, Immigrant Petition for Alien Workers; Form ETA-9089, Application for Permanent Employment Certification, Appendix A-D, Final and Determination; Immigrant Application for Alien and DS-230, Registration of an Immigrant Visa.

You must attach a fully completed Form 8840, Closer Connection Exception Statement for Aliens, to your tax return to claim that you have a closer connection to a foreign country or countries. If you do not have to file a tax return, send the form to: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Center Austin, TX 73301-0215 You must have filed Form 8840 by the due date of Form 1040-NR. The due date for filing the return is explained later in Chapter 7. If you have not filed Form 8840 by the due date, you cannot claim a closer connection to a foreign country or countries. This does not apply if you can demonstrate by clear and convincing evidence that you have taken reasonable steps to know the filing requirements and have taken the important steps to comply with those requirements.

Dual resident aliens. The rules explained here for determining whether you are a resident of the United States do not override the definitions of residence under treaties. If you are a dual resident taxpayer, you can still claim benefits under a tax treaty. A dual resident taxpayer is a resident of both the United States and another country under each country's tax laws. The income tax treaty between the two countries must contain a provision providing for the resolution of conflicting residence claims (the tie-breaker rule).

If you are a dual resident taxpayer and you are claiming treaty benefits, you must file a return using Form 1040-NR with Form 8833 attached and determine your tax status as a nonresident alien. A dual resident taxpayer may also be eligible for assistance from the U.S. tax authority. See Revenue Procedure 2015-40 found on page 236 of the Internal Revenue Bulletin 2015-35, available at IRS.gov/irb/2015-35_IRB#RP-2015-40, or its successor. See How to Declare Treaty Benefits Claimed in Chapter 9 for more information on how to declare treaty benefits.

Foreign students not residents of Barbados and Jamaica, as well as apprentices from Jamaica, may qualify for an election to be treated as resident aliens for U.S. tax purposes under U.S. tax treaties with those countries. See Publication 901 for more information. If you qualify for this election, you may do so by filing Form 1040 and attaching a signed written statement stating your election to your tax return. The rules on foreign residents described in this publication apply to you. Once made, the election applies as long as you remain eligible, and you must obtain permission from the competent authority of the United States to terminate your election.
A resident alien may be a nonresident resident and a resident alien during the same tax year, usually in the year that he enters or leaves the United States.

If you are not required to file a tax return, send the written return to the following address: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Center Austin, TX 73301-0215 You must file the written return on or before the due date of your Form 1040-NR. The due date for filing a tax return is explained in Section 7. If you do not file the required written return as explained above, you cannot claim that you have a closer connection to a foreign country or countries. Therefore, your first day of residence will be the first day you were present in the United States. This does not apply if you can demonstrate by clear and convincing evidence that you took reasonable steps to become aware of the filing requirements for filing the return and took significant steps to comply with those requirements.

If you meet the green card requirement at any time during the calendar year, but do not meet the substantial presence requirement for that year, your residence start date is the first day of the calendar year in which you are present in the United States as a lawful permanent resident.If you meet the substantial presence requirement and the green card requirement, your residence start date is the first day during the year in which you are present in the United States under the substantial presence requirement or as a lawful permanent resident, whichever is earlier.

If you were a resident of the United States for any portion of the previous calendar year and a resident of the United States for any portion of the current year, you will be considered a resident of the United States at the beginning of the current year.

When counting days of residence for conditions (1) and (2), above, do not count days you were in the United States under any of the exceptions above explained under Days of Residence in the United States. If you make the election in the first year, your residence start date for 2024 is the first day of the earliest 31 day period (described in condition (1) above) you use to qualify for election. You are treated as a resident of the United States for the remainder of the year. If you are present for more than a 31 day period and meet condition (2), above, for each of those periods, your residence start date is the first day of the first 31 day period. If you are present for more than a 31 day period but meet condition (2), above, for a subsequent 31 day period, your residence start date is the first day of the subsequent 31 day period.

If you have not met the 2025 requirement by April 15, 2025, you may request an extension of the deadline to file your 2024 Form 1040 or 1040-SR until a reasonable period after you have met that requirement. To request an extension to file your tax return until October 15, 2025, use Form 4868. You may file the paper form or use one of the electronic filing options explained in the instructions for Form 4868. You must pay with this extension the amount of tax you expect to owe for 2024 calculated as if you were a nonresident alien for the entire year. You may use Form 1040-NR to calculate the tax year. You owe the tax on Form 4868. If the taxpayer fails to make a clear payment, you will be charged interest for a reasonable period after you have met that requirement. If you fail to meet the requirements for filing the tax return before the due date of the tax year, you may be subject to a penalty and be convicted by the IRS for failing to meet the requirements for filing the tax return by the first time the tax return is filed and you are not satisfied with the IRS for the first time of the year.

You usually make this choice when you file your joint return. However, you can also make this choice by filing Form 1040-X, Amended U.S. Individual Income Tax Return. Attach Form 1040 or 1040-SR and note  Amended  at the top of the amended return. If you make the choice with the amended return, you and your spouse also have to amend any returns you filed after the year for which you made the choice. Generally, you must file the amended joint return within 3 years from the date you filed your original U.S. income tax return, or within 2 years from the date you paid your income tax for that year, whichever is later.

If you are a resident of the United States during any part of 2025 and were a resident during any part of 2024, you will be treated as a resident until the end of 2024.This applies whether you have a closer connection to a foreign country than to the United States during 2024 and whether you are a resident under the substantial presence requirement or the green card requirement.

If you are not required to file a tax return, send your written return to establish the date of your termination of residency to the following address: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Center Austin, TX 73301-0215 You must file the written return on or before the filing deadline for Form 1040-NR. The filing deadline for filing your tax return is explained in Chapter 7. If you do not file the required written return as discussed above, you cannot claim that you have a closer connection to a foreign country or countries. This does not apply if you can demonstrate by clear and convincing evidence that you have taken reasonable steps to become aware of the filing requirements for a tax return and the important steps you have taken to comply with those requirements.

If, at the end of the tax year, you are married and one spouse is a U.S. citizen or resident alien and the other spouse is a nonresident alien, you may elect to treat the nonresident alien as a resident of the United States. This includes situations where one spouse is a nonresident alien at the beginning of the tax year, but is a resident alien at the end of the year, and the other spouse is a nonresident alien at the end of the year. If you make this choice, you and your spouse are treated as residents for tax purposes for the entire tax year. Neither you nor your spouse can claim under any tax treaty not being residents of the United States.

You usually make this choice when you file your joint return, but you can also make the choice by filing an amended joint return using Form 1040-X. Attach Form 1040 or 1040-SR and note Amended at the top of the corrected return. If you make the choice with an amended return, you and your spouse must also amend any returns you filed after the year for which you made the choice. You generally must file the amended joint return within 3 years of the date you filed your original return or within 2 years of the date you paid your income tax for that year, whichever is later.

Once made, the election to be treated as resident applies to him for all subsequent years unless it is suspended (as explained earlier under How to Suspend the Election) or terminated in one of the following ways. If the election ends in one of the following ways, neither spouse may make this election in any subsequent tax year: 1. Revocation. Either spouse may revoke the election in any subsequent tax year, provided that they make the revocation by the due date for filing their tax return for the tax year. The spouse making the election must attach a signed statement stating that the election is being revoked. The statement must include the name, address and TIN of each spouse. (If one of the spouses dies, the service must include the name and address of the person who revokes the spouse's election in one of the following ways.) If the election ends in one of the following ways, neither spouse may make this election in any subsequent tax year: 1. Revocation. Either spouse may revoke the election in any subsequent tax year, provided that he or she makes the revocation by the due date for filing his or her tax return for the tax year in question. The spouse must file a written return with the income tax return for the first year in which the spouse is domiciled, but must also file a written return for the return for the tax return for the next year, such as the spouse is filing the spouse's income tax return for the tax return. (For example, if the spouse is not filing the spouse is in the receiving the first tax return for the tax return for the tax year)

If you are a nonresident alien in the United States and a bona fide resident of American Samoa or Puerto Rico for the entire tax year, you are subject to taxation, with certain exceptions, under the rules for U.S. resident aliens. For more information, see Bona Fide Residents of American Samoa or Puerto Rico in Chapter 5. If you are a nonresident alien in American Samoa or Puerto Rico who does not qualify as a bona fide resident of American Samoa or Puerto Rico for the entire tax year, you are subject to U.S. taxation as a nonresident alien.

The income of a resident alien is generally subject to U.S. taxation in the same way as the income of U.S. citizens. If you are a resident alien, you must declare all interest, dividends, salaries, or other compensation for services rendered; income from rental property or royalties; and other types of income on your U.S. tax return. You must declare these amounts from sources within and outside the United States.

Nonresident aliens are taxed only on their income from U.S. sources and on certain income related to a U.S. occupation or business (see Chapter 4). The general rules for determining income from U.S. sources that apply to most nonresident aliens are shown in Table 2-1. The discussions below cover the general rules as well as exceptions to these rules.

Real estate is land and buildings and, in general, anything that is built upon, grows on, or is attached to land. Gross income from sources in the United States includes gains, profits, and income from the sale or other disposition of real estate located in the United States.

Revenue from the sale of products from any farm, mine, oil or gas well, other natural reservoir or timber located in the United States and sold in a foreign country, or located in a foreign country and sold in the United States, is partly from U.S. sources. For information on the determination of that part, see Section 1.863-1 (b) of the Regulation.

Movable property is property such as machinery, equipment, furniture, stocks, bonds, and other securities that are not real property. The gain or loss from the sale or exchange of movable property is generally from a U.S. source if you have a tax domicile in the United States. Otherwise, the gain or loss is generally considered to be from a source outside the United States.

Your tax domicile is the general area of your principal place of business, employment or workplace, regardless of where you maintain your household. Your tax domicile is the place where you work permanently or indefinitely as an employee or as a self-employed person. If you do not have a regular or principal place of business because of the nature of your work, then your tax domicile is the place where you live regularly. If you do not fall under any of those categories, you are considered to be an itinerant worker and your tax domicile is wherever you work.

Inventory property is movable property that is stock in trade or that is held primarily for sale to customers in the ordinary course of their occupation or business. The source of income from the sale of inventory that you purchased is determined based on where the property was sold. Generally, this is where the title of the property passes to the buyer. For example, income from the sale of inventory in the United States is from a U.S. source, whether you purchased it in the United States or in a foreign country. The source of income from the sale of inventory property that you produced in the United States and sold outside the United States (or vice versa) is determined based on where the property is produced. These rules apply even if your tax residence is not in the United States.

To determine the source of any gain from the sale of movable property subject to depreciation, one must first calculate the portion of the gain that is not greater than the total of the depreciation adjustments of the property. This portion of the gain is allocated to U.S. sources based on the ratio between the U.S. depreciation adjustments and the total depreciation adjustments. The remainder of this portion of the gain is considered to be from sources outside the United States. For this purpose, U.S. depreciation adjustments are the depreciation adjustments to the property basis that are allowed to calculate the taxable income from U.S. sources. However, if the property is primarily used in the United States during the tax year, all depreciation deductions are for the year allowed as total depreciation adjustments of the property. However, if the depreciation deduction is primarily for certain U.S. sources, the amount of the depreciation deduction will be determined by another method that is normally more useful than the amount of depreciation adjustments for any other sources of income. However, the depreciation deduction for depreciation is usually determined by the amount of depreciation costs incurred by the same source of property, such as the cost of goods sold in the United States or other goods or services purchased in the international market. However, the depreciation deduction for depreciation deduction for depreciation is usually determined by a means of the depreciation of property that property or other goods or services used in the same source of the property.

Intangible assets include patents, copyrights, secret procedures and formulas, trade fund, trademarks, trade names, or other similar assets. The source of the gain from the sale of depreciable or depreciable intangible assets, up to the previously allowable depreciation or depreciation deductions, is determined in the same way as it was determined for the original deductions. This is the same as the source rule for the gain from the sale of assets subject to depreciation. See Depreciation assets, above, for details on how to apply this rule. The source of the gain in excess of the depreciation or depreciation deductions are determined on the basis of the country where the property is used if the income from the sale depends on the productivity, use, or disposal of that property. If the use does not depend on the productivity, or disposal of the property, the previously allowable depreciation or depreciation deductions are determined in the same way as the original deductions. If the source of the income from the property is not the source of the income from the trade fund, the income from the income from the taxable income is determined by the source of the income earnings generated by the fund (disputed income).

Notwithstanding any of the above rules, if you do not have a tax domicile in the United States but maintain an office or other fixed place of business in the United States, treat income from any sale of movable property (including inventory property) that is attributable to that office or place of business as income from U.S. sources. However, this rule does not apply to sales of inventory property for use, disposal, or consumption outside the United States if your office or other fixed place of business outside the United States was substantially involved in the sale. If you have a tax domicile in the United States but maintain an office or other fixed place of business outside the United States, income from sales of movable property, other than inventory, foreign property, or tangible property, that is attributable to that office or place of business abroad could be treated as income from U.S. sources if you had paid income tax on the income from a foreign source. This rule also applies to income tax losses if you had paid income tax on income from a foreign source in a country other than the United States.

The source of a replacement interest payment made to the originator of a security in a securities lending transaction or a put option transaction is determined in the same way as the source of interest on the transferred security.

Interest income from U.S. sources does not include the following: 1. Interest paid by a resident alien or a domestic corporation on bonds issued prior to August 10, 2010 if, for the 3-year period ending with the close of the payer's tax year prior to the payment of interest, at least 80% (0.80) of the total gross income of the payer: 1. Is from sources outside the United States and 2. Is attributable to the active operation of an occupation or business by an individual or corporation in a foreign country or a territory of the United States. However, interest will be considered as interest income from a U.S. source if any of the following apply: 1. The person receiving the interest is related to the resident alien or the domestic corporation. See section 954 (d) for the federal definition of related persons. 2. The interest is payable by a domestic bank or other subsidiary of a foreign corporation, but may be considered to be significantly modified by a foreign bank or cooperative society. 2. The interest is payable by a domestic bank or other subsidiary of a foreign corporation, but may be modified by a domestic bank or other subsidiary of a cooperative society.

In most cases, dividend income received from domestic corporations is income from U.S. sources. Dividend income from foreign corporations is usually income from foreign sources. An exception to the second rule is explained below. The source of an alternative (replacement) dividend payment made to the assignor of a stock exchange security in a securities lending transaction or a put and call transaction is determined in the same way as the source of a distribution of a transferred stock exchange security is determined.

A payment of an amount equivalent to a dividend includes any gross amount that refers to a dividend from a U.S. source and is used to calculate any net amount transferred to or from a taxpayer under a contract, if the taxpayer is the long party under the contract. As a consequence, a taxpayer may be treated as having received a payment equivalent to dividends even if the taxpayer makes a net payment or no amount is paid because the net amount is zero. In 2024, an NPC or ELI will generally be a specified NPC or ELI, respectively, if the contract is a delta one designated transaction. Generally, delta is the ratio between the change in the fair market value of an NPC or ELI and a small change in the fair market value of the number of shares referred to in the contract. Generally, the amount of a dividend equivalent to a specified NPC or ELI for a long party under the contract is multiplied by the amount of the share specified in the contract (see the following information in the ELI Regulation No. 2024-471 (Notice to the Special Purpose Clause) and multiplied by the number of the shares specified in the contract).

The only exceptions to this rule are discussed under Employees of foreign persons, organizations, or offices, below, and under Crew Members, above. If you are an employee and receive compensation for work or personal services performed within and outside the United States, special rules apply to determine the source of compensation. The source of compensation (in addition to certain supplementary benefits) is determined on a time basis. The source of certain supplementary benefits (such as housing and education) is determined on a geographical basis. Or, you may be permitted to use an alternative basis to determine the source of compensation.

If you are selfemployed, you determine the source of compensation for work or personal services of the selfemployed using the basis that most accurately reflects the appropriate source of that income according to the facts and circumstances of your particular case.In many cases, the facts and circumstances will require a pro rata allocation on a time basis, as explained below.

Generally, the multi-year compensation source is determined using the time basis during the period to which the compensation is attributed. Multi-year compensation is compensation that is included in your income in 1 tax year, but is attributable to a period that includes 2 or more tax years. You determine the period to which the compensation is attributed based on the facts and circumstances of your case. For example, the amount of compensation that is specifically related to a time period that includes several calendar years is attributable to the entire multi-year period. The amount of compensation treated as coming from U.S. sources is calculated by multiplying the total of the multi-year compensation by a fraction. The numerator of the fraction is the number of days (or a unit of time less than a day, if applicable) that you worked or provided personal services in the United States in relation to the project. The denominator of the number of days (or a fraction of days, if applicable) that you worked or provided personal services in relation to the project is the number of days (or a fraction of days) that you worked or provided services in the United States in the project.
The amount of supplementary benefits must be reasonable and must be justified by appropriate records or by sufficient evidence.

The source of the above-mentioned supplementary benefits, except for a tax refund or payment for dangerous or difficult service, is determined based on your main place of work. Your main place of work is usually the place where you spend most of your working time. That place can be your office, plant, shop, workshop, or any other location. If there is no single place where you spend most of your working time, your main place of work is the place where the work is focused, such as the place where you report to work or where you are otherwise required to "do" your work. If you have more than one job at any one time, the main location of your work depends on the facts in each case. The most important factors to consider are: the total time you spend in each place, the amount of work you do in each place, and how much money you make in each place.

The source of the supplementary education benefit for the education expenses of your dependants is determined based on the location of your main place of work. A supplementary education benefit includes payments only for the following study expenses in a primary or secondary school: Tuition, school fees, academic tutoring, special needs services for a student with special needs, books, supplies and other equipment. Housing and meals, and uniforms that the school requires or provides in connection with enrolment or attendance.

The source of the local transportation supplement is determined based on the location of your principal place of work. Your local transportation supplement is the amount you receive as compensation for local transportation for you or your spouse or dependents at the location of your principal place of work. The amount treated as a local transportation supplement is limited to the actual expenses incurred for local transportation and the fair rental value of any vehicle provided by the employer used predominantly by you, your spouse or your dependents for local transportation. Actual expenses do not include the cost (including interest) of any vehicle purchased by you or on your behalf.
The source of the supplementary tax refund benefit is determined on the basis of the location of the jurisdiction that imposed the tax for which you are being refunded.

The source of a relocation expense reimbursement is generally based on the location of your new main place of work. However, the source is determined based on the location of your former main place of work if you provide sufficient evidence that such determination of the source is more appropriate given the facts and circumstances of your case. Sufficient evidence generally requires an agreement between you and your employer, or a written statement of company policy, which is put in writing prior to the move and which is made or set out to induce you or other employees to move to another country. The written statement or agreement must state that your employer will reimburse you for the relocation expense you incur to return to your former main place of work, regardless of whether you continue to work for your employer after returning to that location.

If you are an employee, you may determine the source of your compensation using an alternative basis if you establish to the satisfaction of the IRS that, based on the facts and circumstances of your case, the alternative basis more appropriately determines the source of your compensation than the time or geographic basis. If you use an alternative basis, you must retain (and have available for inspection) records to document why the alternative basis more appropriately determines the source of your compensation. In addition, if your total compensation from all sources is $250,000 or more, mark Yes for both questions on Schedule OI, Item K (Form 1040-NR), and attach a written statement to your tax return that states all of the following: 1. Your name and Social Security number (written at the top of the written statement). 2. The specific income or benefit of a specific supplemental benefit for which the alternative basis is used. 3. For each element of the alternative basis, you must keep (and have available for inspection) records to document why the alternative basis more appropriately determines the source of your compensation. For each element of the alternative basis, you must show how the amount of the allowance was calculated using the alternative basis. (2) How much time and how much you earned for each alternative source of compensation was allocated.

Transportation income is income from the use of a ship or aircraft, or from the provision of services directly related to the use of any ship or aircraft. This is true whether the ship or aircraft is owned, contracted, or leased. The phrase ship or aircraft includes any container used in connection with a ship or aircraft. Any transportation income that begins and ends in the United States is treated as derived from U.S. sources. If the transportation begins or ends in the United States, 50% of the transportation income is treated as derived from U.S. sources. For transportation income for personal services, 50% of the income is from U.S. sources if the transportation is between the United States and a U.S. territory. For non-resident aliens, this applies only to income derived from or in connection with an aircraft. The income from the work of one spouse, other than income from an occupation or business, and the distributive share of the profits of a partnership to a partner, is treated as income of the spouse whose services produce the income.

Income derived from a spouse's personal property (and which is not income from work, income from an occupation or business, or income from distributive shares of the income (or loss) of a partnership) is treated as income of that spouse. All other income from matrimonial property is treated in accordance with the laws governing the relevant matrimonial property.

Resident and nonresident aliens are taxed in different ways. Resident aliens are generally taxed in the same way as U.S. citizens. Nonresident aliens are taxed based on the source of their income and whether or not their income is directly related to a U.S. occupation or business. The following explanations will help you determine whether the income you receive during the tax year is directly related to a U.S. occupation or business and how the income is taxed.

Resident aliens are generally subject to taxation in the same way as U.S. citizens. This means that their worldwide income is subject to U.S. taxation and must be reported on their U.S. tax return. The income of resident aliens is subject to the graduated tax rates that apply to U.S. citizens.

The difference between these two categories is that directly related income, after allowable deductions, is taxed at graduated rates. These are the same rates that apply to citizens and residents of the United States. Indirectly related income is subject to a flat rate of 30% (or less under a treaty). If you were previously a U.S. citizen or resident alien, these rules may not apply.

You must generally have been engaged in an occupation or business during the tax year in order to be considered to have received income in that year that is directly related to that occupation or business. Whether or not you are engaged in an occupation or business in the United States depends on the nature of your activities. The following discussions will help you determine whether you are engaged in an occupation or business in the United States.

If you provide personal services in the United States at any time during the tax year, you are normally considered to be engaged in a United States occupation or business.Certain compensation paid to a nonresident alien by a foreign employer is not included in gross income.For more information, see Services Provided to a Foreign Employer in Chapter 3.
Other examples of participation in a U.S. occupation or business are given below.

If you are temporarily present in the United States as a nonimmigrant on an F, J, M, or Q visa, and you did not participate in a U.S. occupation or business, you are considered to have participated in a U.S. occupation or business if you have taxable income from participation in a scholarship or career development grant, as described in section 1441 (b).
If you own and operate a business in the United States selling services, goods or merchandise, you are, with certain exceptions, engaged in a United States occupation or business.

If you are a member of a corporation that is engaged at any time during the tax year in an occupation or business in the United States, you are considered to be engaged in an occupation or business in the United States.
If you are the beneficiary of an inheritance or trust that is engaged in a United States occupation or business, you are treated as if you were engaged in the same occupation or business.

If your sole U.S. business activity is trading in stocks, securities, or commodities (including hedging transactions) through a broker-dealer or other U.S. resident agent, you are not engaged in a U.S. occupation or business. For stock or securities transactions, this applies to any nonresident alien, including a distributor or stock and securities broker. For commodities transactions, this applies to commodities that are normally traded on an organized commodities exchange and to transactions that are normally conducted on that exchange. This discussion does not apply if you have a U.S. office or other fixed place of business at any time during the taxable year through, or under the direction of, a corporation, partnership, partnership, or sole proprietorship that is a U.S. corporation.

You are not engaged in a United States occupation or business if the only business activity you engage in in the United States is conducting trades for your own account in stocks, securities, or commodities. This applies even if the trades are conducted while you are present in the United States or if they are conducted by your employee or your stockbroker or other agent. This does not apply to trades for your own account if you are a stock, securities, or commodities dealer. This does not, however, necessarily mean that, as a dealer, you are deemed to be engaged in a United States occupation or business. Determine this on the basis of the facts and circumstances of each case or the rules mentioned above under the Securities, Stock, Commodities, and Commodities Trading Act.

If you participate in a U.S. occupation or business, any income, gain or loss for the tax year that you obtain from U.S. sources (other than certain investment income) is treated as directly related income. This applies regardless of whether or not there is any connection between the income, and the occupation or business that is carried on in the United States during the tax year. The two requirements described under Investment Income, below, determine whether certain items of investment income (such as interest, dividends, and royalties) are treated as directly related to that business.

Use the two requirements described below to determine whether an item of U.S.-sourced income, which was classified in one of the three categories listed above, and received during the tax year, is directly related to your U.S. occupation or business.If the requirements indicate that the income is directly related, you must include that income with your other directly related income.If the income is not directly related, include it with all other income explained under the 30% tax, later in this chapter.
In general, a corporation's stock is not treated as an asset used in, or held for use in, a United States occupation or business.

Under this requirement, if the conduct of the U.S. occupation or business was a significant factor in the production of the income, the income is considered to be directly related to the occupation or business.

You normally participate in a United States occupation or business when you provide personal services in the United States. The income for personal services you receive in a tax year in which you participate in a United States occupation or business is directly related to a United States occupation or business. The income received in a year other than the year you provided the services is also directly related if it would have been received in the year you provided the services. The income for personal services includes wages, salaries, commissions, fees, daily allowances and employee bonuses. The income may be paid to you in the form of cash services, or goods. If you participate in a United States occupation or business only because you provide personal services in the United States during the tax year, the income and assets are gains and losses, and gains and gains from the exchange or sale of personal assets are not directly related to your occupation or business, or if you have a business relationship with a business, you are entitled to receive income from your occupation or business.

If you were not a resident of the United States when you were a nonresident alien, you are not entitled to receive income from a pension or pension allowance for taxable income in the United States for taxable years after 1986 and, in a subsequent taxable year, you receive distributions from a pension or pension allowance attributable to those services when you were a nonresident alien, those distributions are income directly related to the extent attributable to the contributions.

The concept of "fixed place of business" generally means a place, site, structure, or other similar facility through which you engage in an occupation or business. The concept of "scheduled regular shipping" means that a ship or aircraft follows a published schedule with sailings or flights repeated at regular intervals between the same points for trips or flights that begin or end in the United States. This definition applies to both scheduled air transportation and chartered air transportation. If you do not meet the two conditions above, the income is not directly related and is subject to taxation using the 4% rate. See Transportation Tax, later in this chapter.

All U.S. source profits and losses that are generated from operating a business in the United States are directly related to a U.S. occupation or business. For example, U.S. sales profits from inventory of goods acquired in this country or in a foreign country is income directly related to an occupation or business. A portion of the U.S. source profits and losses of a corporation that participates in a U.S. occupation or business is also directly related to a U.S. occupation or business.

If you are a direct or indirect foreign partner in a U.S. or foreign partnership that participates (or is treated as participating) in an occupation or business within the United States and directly or indirectly disposes of that interest, then the gain or loss from the disposal of that interest in the partnership may affect your federal tax liability. Under section 864 (c) (8), your gain or loss from the sale, exchange or other disposal of that interest in a partnership is treated as directly related to a U.S. occupation or business (directly related gain or directly related loss). However, the amount of the directly related gain or loss is limited by the distributable of what your gain or loss would have been if the partnership had sold all of its related assets at fair market value at the end of the tax year on or after the date of the disposal.
