Any foreign-source income that is equivalent to any type of income described above is treated as directly related to a U.S. occupation or business.For example, interest and dividend equivalents from sources abroad are treated as directly related to an occupation or business in the United States if the income is derived by a foreign person in the active performance of a banking, finance, or similar business within the United States.

Income you receive during the tax year that is directly related to your occupation or business in the United States, after allowable deductions, is subject to the tax rates that apply to U.S. citizens and residents. Generally, you may receive directly related income only if you are a nonresident alien engaged in a U.S. occupation or business during the tax year. However, if you receive payments from the sale or exchange of property, the provision of services, or any other transaction during the tax year in which you are not engaged in a U.S. occupation or business, but such payments would have been treated as directly related income in the year in which the transaction occurred or you provided the services, then they will be treated as directly related income in the tax year in which you received them.

The 30% (or lower under a treaty) rate applies to the gross amount of earnings, profits, or fixed, determinable, annual, or periodic (FDAP) income from U.S. source. Income is fixed when paid in known amounts in advance. Income is determined when there is a basis for calculating the amount to be paid. Income may be periodic if paid from time to time. It does not have to be paid annually or at regular intervals. Income may be determinable or periodic even though the period of time during which payments are made increases or decreases.

Nonresident aliens are generally subject to a 30% tax on gross gaming and gambling income earned in the U.S., if that income is not directly related to a U.S. occupation or business and is not exempt by a treaty. However, no tax is imposed on non-business gaming and gambling income earned by a nonresident alien by playing blackjack (twenty-one), baccarat (point and banker), craps, roulette or big-6 wheel (lucky roulette) in the United States. Net gaming income earned in the United States that is directly related to a U.S. occupation or business by nonresident aliens is subject to income tax at set rates. This income is exempt under some treaties. See Table 1 (Table 1) of the Public Treaties on Taxable U.S. Taxpayers (Treaty), for more information on taxable U.S. taxpayers, which is available in IRS Exhibit Table 915.

A nonresident alien must include 85% of any Social Security benefit (and the equivalent level 1 Social Security portion of the railroad retirement benefit) in annual or periodic fixed or determinable income from U.S. sources. Social Security benefits include monthly retirement, survivor's, and disability benefits. This income is exempt under some tax treaties. See Table 1 in the Tax Treaty Tables, available at IRS.gov/TreatyTables, for a list of treaties that allow Social Security benefits to be exempt from U.S. tax. For more information, see Publication 915.

If you were not engaged in a United States occupation or business and you did not establish a tax year for a prior period, for purposes of the 183 day rule, your tax year will be the calendar year. Furthermore, you must file your tax return on a calendar year basis. If you were in the United States for less than 183 days during the tax year, then capital gains (other than gains listed above) are exempt from taxation, unless they are directly related to a United States occupation or business during your tax year.

Declare your gains and losses from sales or exchanges of capital assets that are not directly related to a U.S. occupation or business on Schedule NEC (Form 1040-NR). Declare your gains and losses from sales or exchanges of capital assets (including real estate) that are directly related to a U.S. occupation or business on Schedule D (Form 1040) or Form 4797, or both, separately. Attach them to Form 1040-NR.

If you have income from real property located in the United States that you own or in which you have an interest and maintain for the production of income, you may elect to treat all income from that property as income directly related to a United States occupation or business. The election applies to all income from real property located in the United States and held for the production of income and to all income from any interest in such property. This includes income from rental, royalties from mining, oil or gas wells or other natural resources. It also includes income from the sale or exchange of U.S. domestic timber, coal, or iron ore with a retained economic interest. You may make this election only for real property income that is not directly related to your U.S. occupation or business. If you make the election, you may claim tax deductions only if you are a resident of the United States and do not participate in the income from any interest in such property during your taxable year, or if you are a resident of another taxable taxable taxpayer who is not participating in your income from a U.S. taxable income taxable business, or who is not a taxable resident during your tax year.

You can revoke the election without IRS approval by filing Form 1040-X for the year you made the election and for subsequent years. You must file Form 1040-X within 3 years from the date you filed your return or within 2 years from when the tax was paid, whichever is later. If this time period expired for the year of the election, you cannot revoke the election for that year.

This 4% tax applies to your gross transportation income of U.S. source. This only includes transportation income that is treated as derived from sources within the United States if the transportation begins or ends in the United States. For transportation income for personal services, the transportation must be between the United States and a U.S. territory. For personal services of a nonresident alien, this only applies to income derived from, or in connection with, an aircraft.

Under this special rule, you are subject to tax on your gross income and earnings from U.S. sources on a net basis at the graduated rates applicable to individuals (with allowable deductions) for the period you were a nonresident alien, unless you were subject to a higher tax under section 871 (rules that normally apply to taxable nonresident alien income, explained above) after taking into account any benefits from a corresponding taxpayer.

If you are subject to this tax for any year in the period in which you were a nonresident alien, you must file Form 1040-NR for that year. The return must be filed by the due date (including any extensions) of filing your U.S. income tax return for the year in which you became a U.S. resident again. If you have already filed returns for that period, you must file amended returns. You must attach a written statement to your tax return identifying the source of all your U.S. and foreign gross income and the types of income subject to this special rule.

The following section describes the expatriation rules under section 877A that apply to individuals who have expatriated on or after June 17, 2008. See Expatriation After June 16, 2008, below. If you expatriated before June 17, 2008, see Expatriation After June 3, 2004, and Before June 17, 2008 in Chapter 4 of Publication 519 of 2018 and Instructions for Form 8854 of 2018. If you renounced your citizenship or ended your long-term residence after June 3, 2004, and before June 17, 2008, you will still be considered a U.S. citizen or resident for tax purposes until you file your expatriation notice with the Department of State or the IRS and file your Form 8854 with the Department of Homeland Security.
Your expatriation date is the date on which you renounce your U.S. citizenship (in the case of a former citizen) or end your long-term residency (in the case of a former U.S. resident).

You must file an initial Form 8854 in the year you renounce your U.S. citizenship or end your long-term residency, even if you are not a covered expatriate.In addition, you must file a Form 8854 annually after you expatriate if you are a covered expatriate and you: 1. have deferred payment of the market value tax (see Deferred payment of the market value tax) below; 2. have an eligible deferred compensation item; or 3. have an interest in an ungranted trust.
For more information on deferred payment, see the Instructions for Form 8854.

You are deemed to have renounced your U.S. citizenship on the earlier of the following dates: 1. the date you renounced your U.S. citizenship before a diplomatic or consular officer of the United States (provided that the voluntary renunciation is subsequently confirmed by the issuance of a certificate of loss of citizenship). 2. the date you provided the Department of State with a signed statement of your voluntary renunciation of your U.S. citizenship confirming the performance of an act of naturalization (provided that the voluntary renunciation is subsequently confirmed by the issuance of a certificate of loss of citizenship). 3. the date the Department of State issued the certificate of loss of citizenship. 4. the date a U.S. court cancelled your naturalization certificate.

You are considered to have ended your long-term residence on the earlier of the following dates: 1. The date you voluntarily renounced your lawful permanent resident status by filing Form I-407 with the Department of Homeland Security with a United States immigration or consular officer. 2. The date you became subject to a final administrative order that you abandoned your lawful permanent resident status (or, if the order is appealed, the date of the final court order issued in connection with such administrative order). 3. The date you became subject to a final administrative order for your removal from the United States under the Immigration and Nationality Act. 4. If you were an alien with dual residency in the United States and in a country with which the United States has a tax treaty, the date you began to be treated as a resident of that country under the provisions of the tax treaty and notified the IRS on Form 8885 and the Treatment of Foreign Nationals for Double Residence in Chapter 1 of the V332.

If you expatriated after June 16, 2008, you are treated as a covered expatriate, and the expatriation rules under section 877A apply to you if you meet any of the following conditions: (1) Your annual average net income tax for the 5 years ended before the date of your expatriation or termination of your residency is more than $201,000 if you expatriated or terminated your residency in 2024. (2) Your net worth is $2 million or more on the date of your expatriation or termination of your residency. (3) You did not certify on Form 8854 that you met all United States federal tax obligations for the 5 years prior to the date of your expatriation or termination of your residency.

If you were a U.S. citizen who expatriated after March 18, 2010, you may be eligible for certain relief procedures that provide alternative means to satisfy the tax compliance process.For more information, see Procedures for Relief of Certain Expatriates.

You may qualify for the exemption described above if the following conditions apply: You became a U.S. citizen and a citizen of another country at birth and, as of the date of your expatriation, you continue to be a citizen of, and are subject to tax as a resident of, that other country. You have been a resident of the United States for no more than 10 years during the 15-year tax period ending with the tax year during which the expatriation occurs. For the purpose of determining residence in the United States, use the substantial presence requirement described in chapter 1.

You may be eligible for the exemption described above if you meet both of the following requirements: you expatriated before you were 18 1⁄2 years of age; you have been a resident of the United States for no more than 10 taxable years before the expatriation occurred; for the purpose of determining residence in the United States, use the substantial presence requirement described in chapter 1.

In the year in which you expatriate, you are subject to income tax on the unrealized net gain (or loss) on your property as if the property had been sold at its fair market value on the day before the date of expatriation (market value tax). This applies to most property interests you held on the date of renunciation of citizenship or termination of residency. But see Exceptions, below. Gains from considered sales are to be accounted for for the tax year of the considered sale regardless of other laws of the United States Internal Revenue Code. Losses from considered sales are to be accounted for to the extent otherwise provided for under the laws of the United States Internal Revenue Code. However, section 1091 (but relating to the fictitious sale of property) does not apply unless the net gain or loss from the expatriated sale was reduced to $866,000 and included in your income from your residence.

Instead, items (1) and (3) may be subject to withholding tax. In the case of item (2), you are treated as having received the present value of your accrued benefit as of the day before your expatriation date. In the case of item (4), you are treated as having received a distribution of your total interest in the account on the day before your expatriation date. See Notice 2009-85 (Notice 2009-85) and the Instructions for Form 8854 for more information.

After you have determined your status as an alien, the source of your income, and whether that income is taxed in the United States and how, your next step is to calculate the tax. The information in this chapter is not as extensive for resident aliens as it is for nonresident aliens. Resident aliens should obtain publications, forms, and instructions for U.S. citizens, because the information for filing tax returns for resident aliens is generally the same as for U.S. citizens. If you are a nonresident alien and a resident alien in the same tax year, see chapter 6 for a discussion of dual resident aliens.

If you are a nonresident alien, you may be entitled to some of the same itemized deductions that resident aliens are entitled to claim. However, nonresident aliens may claim itemized deductions only if they have income directly related to their occupation or business in the United States. There may be limitations that affect the amount of itemized deductions you can claim on Schedule A. See the Instructions for Schedule A (Form 1040) or Instructions for Schedule A (Form 1040-NR)  Detailed Deductions on the Instructions for Form 1040-NR.

If you are a resident alien, you may claim the same itemized deductions as U.S. citizens using the Instructions for Schedule A (Form 1040). See the Instructions for Schedule A (Form 1040) for more information. If you do not specify deductions, you may claim the standard deduction for your marital status for tax purposes.

You may claim certain itemized deductions if you receive income directly related to your occupation or business in the United States. You generally can only include deductions and losses that are appropriately allocated and prorated to income directly related to a U.S. occupation or business. You cannot include deductions and/or losses that are related to tax-exempt income or income not directly related to a U.S. occupation or business. However, you may deduct certain charitable donations and losses due to a fortuitous event or theft even if these are not related to your directly related income.

See the Instructions for Form 4684 for more information on qualified net loss for disaster relief.To determine if you were affected by a major disaster declared by the federal government, visit IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief.
These losses are not subject to the limitations that apply to personal use property.

A special rule applies to students and business apprentices who qualify for the benefits of Section 21 (2) of the U.S.-India Tax Treaty.These may claim the standard deduction, provided they do not claim itemized deductions.Use Worksheet 5-1 to calculate your standard deduction for 2024.If you are married and your spouse files a return and details the deductions, you cannot take the standard deduction.

If you are a student or business apprentice who qualifies for the benefits of Section 21 (2) of the U.S.-India Tax Treaty that has been affected by a major (major) disaster declared as such by the federal government in 2024 (see IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief and FEMA.gov/disaster), you may elect to increase your standard deduction by the amount of your qualified net disaster losses related to your personal property casualty losses on your 2024 tax return.

You may deduct state and local income taxes on income you paid on income directly related to your occupation or business in the United States.Your deduction is limited to a combined total deduction of $10,000 ($5,000 if you are married filing separately).If you received a refund or refund in 2024 for taxes you paid in a previous year, do not reduce your deduction by that amount.Instead, you must include the refund or refund in your income if you deducted taxes in the previous year and the deduction reduced your income tax.See Recoveries in Publication 525 for details on how to calculate the amount to include in your income.

You may deduct your charitable donations or gifts to qualified organizations subject to certain limits. Qualified organizations include organizations that are religious, charitable, educational, scientific, or literary in nature, or that work to prevent cruelty to children or animals. Certain organizations that promote national or international sports competitions for non-professional players are also qualified organizations. For more information on the charitable donation deduction, see Charitable Donations to U.S. Organizations under Instructions for Schedule A (Form 1040-NR)  Detailed deductions in the Instructions for Form 1040-NR.

Donations made directly to a foreign charitable organization are not deductible. However, you may deduct donations made to a U.S. organization that transfers funds to a foreign charitable organization if the U.S. organization controls the use of the funds or if the foreign organization is only an administrative branch of the U.S. organization. According to a limited number of tax treaties, you may qualify to deduct donations made to a foreign charitable organization. See Publication 526 for details.

You may be able to deduct casualty losses and theft on your tax return. You may only deduct a casualty loss or non-business theft if this loss is attributable to a federally declared disaster. If your casualty loss or theft is attributable to a federally declared disaster, you may deduct your loss even if your property is not related to an occupation or business in the United States. The property may be personal use or income-generating property not related to an occupation or business in the United States. The property must be located in the United States at the time of the casualty or theft.
For more information, see the instructions for line 7 under Instructions for Schedule A (Form 1040-NR) Detailed deductions in the Instructions for Form 1040-NR. See also Publication 529.
Resident aliens generally claim tax credits and report tax payments, including withholding, using the same rules that apply to U.S. citizens.The following items are some of the credits you can claim.

You may claim a credit, subject to certain limits, for income taxes paid to or accrued with a foreign country on income from foreign sources. You may not claim a credit for income taxes paid or accrued on income from foreign sources excluded. To claim a credit for income taxes paid to or accrued with a foreign country, you will generally need to file Form 1116 along with your Form 1040 or 1040-SR. For more information, see Publication 514.

You could take this credit if you pay someone else to care for your qualifying child under the age of 13 whom you claim as your dependent, or your disabled dependent or disabled spouse, so that you can work or look for work.
You may qualify for this credit if you are 65 years of age or older or if you retired with a total and permanent disability.

You may qualify for these credits if you paid qualified tuition expenses for yourself, your spouse, or a dependent.There are two education credits: the opportunity tax credit for Americans and the lifetime learning credit.You cannot claim these credits if you are married filing separately.Use Form 8863 to calculate the credit.For more information, see Publication 970.
You may qualify for this credit (also known as the  saver's credit ) if you made qualified contributions to an employer-sponsored retirement plan or IRA arrangement in 2024.

If you did not have an SSN (or ITIN) issued on or before the due date to file your 2024 return (including extensions), you cannot claim the child tax credit for 2024 on either your original return or the amended return. If your child did not have a valid SSN for work issued before the due date to file your 2024 return (including extensions), you cannot claim the child tax credit for this child but could claim the credit for other dependents for this child.

The other dependent credit is for people who have dependents who cannot be claimed for the child tax credit. The qualifying dependent must be a U.S. citizen or national or resident alien and have an SSN, ITIN, or ATIN issued on or before the due date for filing their 2024 tax return (including extensions). See Schedule 8812 (Form 1040) and its instructions for more information.

You may qualify for a tax credit of up to $16,810 for qualified expenses paid to adopt a qualifying child.This amount may be allowed for the adoption of a special needs child regardless of whether you have qualified expenses.To claim the adoption credit, file Form 8839, Qualified Adoption Expenses, with your Form 1040 or 1040-SR.
The taxable person is entitled to a tax credit for the period of residence of the person concerned, which is equal to the taxable person's annual income tax.

If you receive income from foreign sources that is directly related to an occupation or business in the United States, you may claim a credit for any income tax you paid to or accrued with a foreign country or U.S. territory on that income. If you do not have income from foreign sources that is directly related to an occupation or business in the United States, you may not claim credits against your U.S. taxes for taxes you paid to or accrued with a foreign country or U.S. territory. You may not take any credit for taxes imposed by a foreign country or U.S. territory on your income from U.S. sources if those taxes were imposed only because you are a citizen or resident of the foreign country or territory. If you claim a credit for foreign income tax, you will generally have to file a 1116. See Publication Form 514 for more information.

You could take this credit if you pay someone else to care for your qualifying child under the age of 13 whom you claim as your dependent, or your disabled dependent or disabled spouse, so that you can work or look for work. For definitions of these terms, see Publication 503. Married nonresident aliens can claim the credit only if they choose to file a joint return with a spouse who is a U.S. citizen or resident as explained under How to Make the Election in chapter 1, or if they qualify as certain married persons who do not live together (see Joint Return Test (Joint Reporting Requirement) in Publication 503). The amount of your child and minor dependent care expenses that qualify for the credit in any tax year cannot be more than the amount of your U.S. work income for that tax year. For more information, see Publication 503.
Additional information on the Opportunity Tax Credit for Americans is available at IRS.gov/AOTC.
For more information, please see Publication 590-A.

If your child did not have a valid SSN for work and was issued before the due date for filing the 2024 return (including extensions), you cannot claim the child tax credit for this child, but you could claim the child tax credit for other dependents for this child. See Credit for Other Dependents below. Use Schedule 8812 (Form 1040) and instructions for calculating your credits.

This is a nonrefundable credit of $500 per qualified person. The qualified dependent must be a U.S. citizen or national or resident alien. See the Instructions for Form 1040-NR. To claim the credit for dependents, your dependents must have an SSN, ITIN, or ATIN issued on or before the due date for filing their 2024 tax return (including extensions). Only United States nationals; residents of Canada, Mexico, and South Korea; or residents of India who were students or apprentices of businesses who qualify for the benefits of Article 21 (2) of the Tax Treaty between the United States and India may claim the credit for dependents.

To claim the adoption credit, file Form 8839 with your Form 1040-NR. Married nonresident aliens may claim the credit only if they choose to file a joint return with a spouse who is a U.S. citizen or resident as explained under Nonresident Spouse Treated as a Resident in chapter 1, or if they qualify as certain married persons not living together (see Married Persons Not Filing Jointly in the Instructions for Form 8839).
If you paid the alternative minimum tax in a previous year, use Form 8801 and its instructions to see if you qualify for this credit.
You can claim the withholding tax for the year as a payment against your U.S. tax. You claim it on lines 25a to 25g of your Form 1040-NR. The withholding tax reduces any tax you owe on Form 1040-NR.

Any federal income tax withheld from your wages during the tax year while you were a nonresident alien is allowed as payment against your U.S. income tax liability for that same year.You may claim the withheld income tax regardless of whether or not you engaged in an occupation or business in the United States during the year, and whether or not the wages (or any other income) were related to an occupation or business in the United States.

If you had two or more employers, you could claim a credit against your U.S. income tax liability for Social Security tax withheld in excess of the required maximum.See Social Security and Medicare taxes in Chapter 8 for more information.

If you are a shareholder in a mutual fund (or other regulated investment company (RIC)) or real estate investment trust (REIT), you may claim a credit on your part for any taxes paid by the company on your undistributed long-term capital gains.This information will be given to you on a Form 2439 which you will need to attach to your tax return.

You can claim as a payment against any withholding tax on investments and other fixed or determinable income paid to you annually or periodically (FDAP).Fixed or determinable income includes income from interest, dividends, rents, and royalties that you do not claim as directly related income.Payments from wages or salaries may be fixed or determinable income to you, but are usually subject to withholding as discussed above.Taxes on fixed or determinable income are withheld at a rate of 30% or less under a tax treaty.

If you are a foreign partner in a partnership, the partnership will withhold tax on your share of the directly related taxable income from the partnership. The partnership will provide you with a statement on Form 8805 showing the withheld tax. A partnership whose shares are listed on a stock exchange may withhold on its current distributions of directly related income. In such a case, the partnership will provide you with a statement on Form 1042-S. Claim the withheld tax as a payment on line 25e or 25g of Form 1040-NR, as applicable.

If you are a direct or indirect foreign partner in a U.S. corporation or foreign partnership that participates (or is treated as participating) in an occupation or business within the United States and you directly or indirectly dispose of that participation that results in a gain, then for transfers that occur after 2017, the transferee will generally withhold and pay to the IRS on your behalf a tax equal to 10% of the amount received on the sale. The rules for withholding and paying this amount are similar to those for sales of shares in U.S. real estate. You will receive a Form 8288-A showing the withheld amount that you can then claim on line 25 of your Form 1040-NR as a credit against the tax due on the gain. You may be able to provide certain information to the transferee to reduce or eliminate the withholding requirement. For example, if a transfer occurs after 2017, the transferee will generally withhold and pay to the IRS a tax equal to 10% of the amount received on the sale. The rules for withholding and paying this amount are similar to those for sales of shares in U.S.S. real estate. You will receive a Form 8288-A showing the withheld amount that you can then claim on line 25 of your Form 1040-NR as a credit against the tax due on the gain. You may be able to provide certain information to the transferee to reduce or eliminate the withholding of the transfer.

You may claim as a payment any tax withheld in respect of the sale of a U.S. real estate interest (or income treated as derived from the sale of a U.S. real estate interest). See Property Gain or Loss in Chapter 4 above. The buyer will give you a statement of the amount withheld on a Form 8288-A. You may claim the withheld tax as a payment on line 25f of Form 1040-NR.

When you complete your tax return, take special care to write down the correct amount of any withheld tax shown on your tax return.The following table lists some common tax return documents and shows you where to find the amount of withheld tax.

If you are a nonresident alien who is a bona fide resident of American Samoa or Puerto Rico for the entire tax year, you are generally taxed in the same manner as resident aliens. You must file Form 1040 or 1040-SR and declare all of your income from sources within and outside the United States. However, you may exclude income mentioned in the following paragraphs. However, for tax purposes other than income tax return, you will be treated as a nonresident alien. For example, you are not allowed the standard deduction, you cannot file a joint return, and you cannot claim a dependent, unless that person is a U.S. citizen or national. There are also limits on what deductions and credits are allowed.

If you are a bona fide resident of Puerto Rico for the entire year, you may exclude from your gross income all income from sources within Puerto Rico (other than amounts for services rendered as an employee of the United States or any of its agencies). If you report your income on a calendar year basis and have no wages subject to withholding for 2024, file your return and pay your tax by June 16, 2025. You must also make your first payment of estimated income tax for 2025 by June 16, 2025.

If you are a bona fide resident of American Samoa for the entire year, you may exclude from your gross income all income from sources within American Samoa (other than amounts for services rendered as an employee of the United States or any of its agencies).[1] An employee of the government of American Samoa is not considered to be an employee of the government of the United States or any of its agencies for purposes of the exclusion.

If you have previously established a regular tax year (12 consecutive months ending on the last day of a month other than December or a 52-year or 53-year tax year) and are a U.S. resident in any calendar year, you will be treated as a resident of the United States for any portion of your tax year that corresponds to that calendar year.

The amount of your tax depends on your marital status for tax purposes.Your marital status for tax purposes is important in determining whether you can take certain deductions and credits.The rules for determining your marital status for tax purposes are different for resident and non-resident aliens.

U.S. citizens may use the same marital status for filing purposes as is available to U.S. citizens. See the instructions for your form or Publication 501 for more information on marital status for filing purposes.

Generally, you may file as a married person filing a joint return only if you and your spouse were both U.S. citizens or resident aliens during the entire tax year, or if you choose to be a nonresident spouse treated as a resident, as explained in chapter 1.

If your spouse died in 2022 or 2023 and you did not remarry before the end of 2024, you may qualify to file as a qualifying surviving spouse and use the tax rates for joint filing of taxable income tax. This applies only if you could have filed a joint tax return with your spouse for the year your spouse died. For more information on marital status for purposes of a qualifying surviving spouse return, see Surviving Spouse Meets the Marital Status Requirements for Declaration Effects in the Instructions for Form 1040 of 2024.

You may qualify as a resident head of household if you are not married or if you are considered unmarried on the last day of the year and you paid more than half the cost of maintaining a dwelling for yourself and a qualifying person. You must be a resident alien during the entire tax year. You are considered unmarried for this purpose if your spouse was a nonresident alien during some time of the year and your spouse does not choose to be treated as a resident, as explained in chapter 1 under Nonresident Spouse Treaty as a Resident.
If you are a nonresident alien filing Form 1040-NR, you may be able to use one of the civil status statements for tax purposes that are explained below.

Married nonresident aliens who are not married to U.S. citizens or residents generally have to use the married tax return column of the Tax Table or Tax Calculation Worksheet when determining income tax on income directly related to a U.S. occupation or business.

Married nonresident aliens are not normally able to use the Tax Table column or the Single Person Tax Calculation Worksheet. However, you may be able to file as single if you lived separately from your spouse for the last 6 months of the year and you are a resident of Canada, Mexico, or South Korea who is married, or if you are a U.S. national who is married. See the Instructions for Form 1040-NR to see if you qualify.

An individual who, despite not being a U.S. citizen, owes allegiance to the United States is considered a U.S. national. In addition, U.S. nationals include American Samoans (American Samoa) and Normans (Northern Mariana Islands) who chose to become U.S. nationals instead of U.S. citizens.
If your spouse died in 2022 or 2023 and you did not remarry before the year 2024 ended, you may be eligible to file as a qualifying surviving spouse and use the joint tax rates for joint returns.

You cannot file as a head of household if you are a nonresident alien at any time during the tax year. However, if you are married, your spouse could qualify as a head of household if: Your spouse is a resident alien or U.S. citizen during the entire tax year; You do not elect to be treated as a resident alien; and Your spouse meets the other requirements for this marital status for the purposes of filing, as explained above under Resident Aliens.

The taxable income of a non-resident alien who uses Form 1040-NR must be used to determine the tax rates in Schedule W in the Instructions for Form 1040-NR when determining taxable income directly related to an occupation or business in the United States.

A nonresident alien who is a bona fide resident of American Samoa or Puerto Rico for the entire taxable year and who is temporarily working in the United States should consult Bona Fide Residents of American Samoa or Puerto Rico at the end of this chapter for information on these special rules.

You must declare each item of income that is taxable according to the rules in Chapters 2, 3, and 4.For resident aliens, this includes income from sources both inside and outside the United States.For nonresident aliens, this includes both income directly related to a United States occupation or business (subject to graduated tax rates) and income from sources within the United States that are not directly related (subject to a flat tax rate of 30% or less under a tax treaty).

Resident aliens and nonresident aliens may claim similar deductions on their U.S. tax returns, but nonresident aliens generally can claim only deductions related to income directly related to their U.S. occupation or business.

You may claim the same deductions as are allowed to U.S. citizens if you are a resident alien during the entire tax year.Although the discussion below under Nonresident Aliens contains some of the same general rules and guidelines that apply to you, it is specifically directed to nonresident aliens.You should obtain the Instructions for Form 1040 for more information on how to claim your allowable deductions.

You may claim deductions to calculate your directly related taxable income (DIRT).In general, you cannot claim deductions related to income that is not directly related to your activities in the United States.Except for certain detailed deductions, explained below, you may claim deductions only to the extent that they relate to your directly related income.

You may deduct all ordinary and necessary expenses of carrying on your occupation or business in the United States to the extent that they relate to income directly related to that occupation or business.

If you paid interest in 2024 on a qualified student loan, you may be able to deduct up to $2,500 of the interest you paid. You can usually claim the deduction if you meet all the requirements. The deduction is claimed on line 21 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040).

If you have income directly related to a U.S. occupation or business, you may deduct up to 20% of your qualifying business income from your qualifying occupation or business, plus 20% of your qualifying dividends from a real estate investment trust (REIT) or income (loss) from a qualifying publicly traded partnership (PTP). For more information, see Line 13a in the Instructions for Form 1040-NR. For more information on the qualifying business income deduction, see Form 8995, Form 8995-A and its appendices and the related instructions for the relevant forms and appendices.

You may deduct losses arising from transactions you have made for profit and which have not been reimbursed by insurance, etc., to the extent that they relate to income directly related to a United States occupation or business.

If you are a qualifying educator in 2024, you may deduct as an adjustment to your income up to $300 of qualifying unreimbursed expenses you paid or incurred during 2024 for certain professional development courses and for books, supplies (other than items for health or physical education courses that are not used in the performance of sports), computer equipment (including computer software and related services), and other supplemental equipment and supplies used in the classroom. For more information, see the instructions on your tax form. Qualifying expenses include amounts paid or incurred in 2024 for personal protective equipment, disinfectants, and other supplies used to prevent the spread of coronavirus.

The moving expenses deduction is only available if you are a member of the United States Armed Forces on active duty and, due to a military order, you are moving because of a permanent change of station. For more information, see Publication 3, Armed Forces Tax Guide. If you qualify, use Form 3903 to calculate the amount to be deducted.

Do not include in income the value of moving and storage services provided by the government because of a move that is because of a military order resulting from a permanent change of station.Similarly, do not include in income amounts received as a relocation allowance, temporary accommodation expenses, temporary accommodation allowance, or moving allowance.For more information, see Publication 3.

If you are self-employed, you may be able to deduct contributions to a SEP, a SIMPLE, or a qualified retirement plan that provides retirement benefits for you and your employees under common law, if any. To make deductible contributions for yourself, you must have net self-employment income that is directly related to your occupation or business in the United States. See Publication 560, Retirement Plans for Small Business, for more information.

You must include in your income any directly related interest income that you receive or that is credited to your account during the year. Do not reduce it by any penalty that you have to pay because you withdrew funds prematurely from a term or fixed-term deposit. However, if the interest income is directly related to your occupation or business in the United States, you may deduct on line 18 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040) the amount of the early withdrawal penalty that the banking institution charged you.
If you do not enter your SSN, ITIN or an ATIN in the dependents section of your tax return when required, or if you enter an incorrect number, you may be denied certain tax benefits.

If you are a resident alien, a qualifying dependent includes your qualifying child or qualifying relative. There are five requirements that must be met for a child to be your qualifying child. There are four requirements that must be met for a person to be your qualifying relative. For more information, see the Instructions for Form 1040. If you do not enter your SSN, ITIN, or ATIN in the Dependents section of your tax return when it is required, or if you enter an incorrect number, you may be denied certain tax benefits.
If you are a resident of Mexico or Canada, or a U.S. citizen, you may claim that each of your dependents meets certain requirements.

A nonresident alien residing in South Korea (who is not an employee of the South Korean government) may be able to claim his or her child as a qualifying dependent.In addition to using the same rules as U.S. citizens to determine who is a dependent, under the tax treaty with South Korea, the child must have lived with the nonresident alien in the United States at some point during the tax year.

Students and apprentice businessmen who qualify for benefits under Article 21 (2) of the US-India Tax Treaty may claim income from their dependents if they meet the same rules as apply to US citizens.

You have a dual tax year when you have been both a resident alien and a nonresident alien in the same year. Dual residency does not refer to your citizenship; it refers only to your status of resident in the United States. When determining your U.S. income tax liability for a dual tax year, different rules apply for the part of the year in which you are a resident of the United States and the part of the year in which you are not a resident. The most common dual tax years are the years of arrival and departure.

If you are a resident alien on the last day of your tax year and you report income on a calendar year basis, you must file your return no later than April 15 of the year following the close of your tax year (however, see AUTHORITY, below). If you report income on a year other than the calendar year, you must file your return no later than the 15th day of the fourth month following the close of your tax year. In either case, you must file your return by sending it to the address for dual resident aliens listed at the back of the Instructions for Forms 1040 and 1040-SR. If you are a resident alien on the last day of your tax year and you report income on a calendar year basis, you must file your return no later than April 15 of the year following the close of your tax year if your wages are subject to withholding tax. If you do not file your return on a calendar year, you must file your return no later than the 15th day of the fourth month following the close of your tax year. If you do not file your return by the end of the tax year, you must file your return by the end of the following calendar year. If you do not file your return by the end of the fourth month following the tax year, you must file your return by the end of the following calendar year. If you have previously established a regular tax year (12 consecutive months ending on the last day of a month other than December, or a year of 52 or 53 weeks) and are considered a resident of the United States in any calendar year, you will be treated as a resident of the United States for any portion of your tax year that falls within that calendar year.

However, income from sources outside the United States that are not directly related to a foreign occupation or business is not taxable even if it was earned while you were a nonresident alien or if you became a nonresident alien after receiving it and before the end of the year. During the part of the year that you are a nonresident alien, you are subject to income taxes on income from U.S. sources and on certain income from foreign sources that are treated as directly related to a U.S. occupation or business. The rules for treating income from which foreign sources as directly related to the United States are explained in chapter 4 under Foreign Income. However, income from sources outside the United States that are not directly related to a foreign occupation or business is not taxable even if you received it while you were a nonresident alien or if you became a nonresident alien after receiving it and before the end of the year. All three types of losses refer to a federally declared disaster, but the requirements are different for each type of loss. A "federally declared disaster" is one that the President of the United States has determined meets the requirements for receiving federal relief under the Stafford Act. A federally declared disaster includes (a) a major disaster declaration or (b) an emergency declaration under the Stafford Act.

A federal casualty loss by an individual is a casualty loss or theft of property for personal use that is attributable to a federally declared disaster. The loss must occur in a state that has received a federal disaster declaration. You are eligible to claim a casualty deduction if you suffered a federal casualty loss. If you suffered a casualty loss or theft of property for personal use that is not attributable to a federally declared disaster, it is not a federal casualty loss and you cannot claim a casualty deduction unless you qualify for the exception.

A disaster loss is a loss that is attributable to a federally declared disaster and that occurs in an area (zone) qualified to receive relief under a Presidential declaration. The disaster loss must occur in a county that qualifies for public or individual relief (or both). Disaster losses are not limited to property for the personal use of an individual and may be claimed by an individual's commercial or income-generating property and by corporations, S corporations, and partnerships. If you suffered a disaster loss, you are eligible to claim a fortuitous deduction and may elect to claim the loss in the preceding tax year. See Disaster Zones, below.

A qualified disaster loss of an individual includes a casualty loss or theft of personal use property that is attributable to: A major (major) disaster declared as such by the President pursuant to section 401 of the Stafford Act in 2016; Hurricane Harvey; Tropical Storm Harvey; Hurricane Irma; Hurricane Maria; The California wildfires in 2017 and January 2018; A major disaster declared as such by the President pursuant to section 401 of the Stafford Act before February 19, 2020 for a disaster that occurred in 2018 or during 2019, but before December 21, 2019, and which did not continue after January 19, 2020 (except for those losses attributable to the California wildfires in January 2018 (which have already received prior alibis) and a major disaster declared as such by the President during the period of January 1, 2020 and January 28, 2025, and a disaster that did not occur before or after January 10, 2019 and that did not occur on or after January 28, 2024, and a disaster that did not occur on or after January 12, 2019 and that did not occur on or after January 10, 2019 or January 28, 2025, and a disaster that did not occur on or after January 10, 2019 and did not occur on or after January 11, 2025, and that did not occur on or after January 28, 2024.

For tax years 2018 to 2025, fortuitous losses of personal use property sustained by an individual are deductible only if they are attributable to a federally declared disaster (federal fortuitous loss). Personal use property is any other than a commercial property or income-generating property. If the event by which you suffered a personal casualty loss (not attributable to a federally declared disaster) occurred before January 1, 2018, but you did not sustain the casualty loss until January 1, 2018, or after, the casualty loss is not deductible.

A casualty loss is not deductible, even to the extent that this loss does not exceed your casual gain of property for personal use, if the damage or destruction was caused by: The accidental breaking of items such as glasses or fine tableware in normal conditions. A family pet (as explained below). A fire, if you deliberately start it or pay someone to start it. A car accident, if it is caused by your negligence or deliberate act. This also applies if the act or negligence of another person acting on your behalf caused the accident.
The death of a pet is not deductible as a casualty loss unless the requirements of the above-mentioned casualty are met.

Loss of property due to progressive deterioration is not deductible as a fortuitous event. This is because the damage occurs as a result of a continually operating cause or normal process, rather than as a result of a sudden event. Below are some examples of damage caused by progressive deterioration: The continual weakening of a building due to normal wind and weather conditions. The deterioration and damage caused to a water heater that explodes. However, rust and water damage to carpets and curtains when the heater is running is considered a fortuitous event. Most property losses due to drought are deductible. For a drought-related loss to be deductible, it usually has to occur in the course of a business or in transactions involving unexpected insect or other insect infestation or damage to the land for profit. However, it can occur due to a sudden loss of trees, trees, or other plants, or a sudden loss of crops, trees, or other plant materials, or a sudden damage caused by a common cause, such as a tree infestation, insect or other plant disease.

Because the casualty losses claimed under this special procedure are not attributable to a federally declared disaster, you could only deduct them to the extent that they do not exceed your casualty property gains for personal use. For the 2018 to 2025 tax years, fortuitous losses of personal use property sustained by an individual are deductible only if they are attributable to a federally declared disaster (federal fortuitous loss). An exception to the rule that limits the deduction of losses by fortuitous event or theft of personal use property to federal fortuitous losses applies if you have fortuitous gains from personal use property. If so, you may deduct your fortuitous losses of personal use property not attributable to a federally declared disaster to the extent that they do not exceed your fortuitous gains from personal use property (e.g., if you have a personal use property that was damaged by a fire or fire) or your personal property that was damaged by a fire or fire.

You may not deduct as a loss for theft the decrease in value of shares you acquired on the open market for investment purposes if the decrease is caused by disclosure of accounting fraud or other unlawful conduct by the officers or directors of the entity that issued the shares. However, you may be able to deduct it as a loss of capital on Schedule D (Form 1040) when you sell or exchange the shares or if the shares lose their value entirely. For more information on the sale of shares, valuation loss, valuation loss and capital loss, see Chapter 4 of Publication 550.

The mere disappearance of money or property does not constitute theft. However, an accidental loss or disappearance of property may be considered as a fortuitous event if it is the result of an identifiable event that occurs suddenly, unexpectedly, or uncommonly. Sudden, unexpected, and uncommon events are defined in the previous section titled Fortuitous Event.

To be able to deduct a loss for accidental death or theft, you must be able to prove that such accidental death or theft occurred.You must also be able to prove the amount you claim as a deduction as explained below.

If there is a casualty loss, you must be able to show all of the following: that you owned the property or, if you rented it from someone else, had contractual liability to the owner for the damage; the type of casualty (car accident, fire, storm, etc.) and the date it occurred; that the loss occurred as a direct result of the casualty; whether there is a claim for reimbursement with reasonable expectations of receiving it.
For personal use goods, apply the deduction limits explained below to calculate the amount of loss you can deduct.

If you receive any insurance or other reimbursement payments, you must subtract the amount of the reimbursement when calculating the loss. It will not be casualty loss or theft the part that you are reimbursed. If in the year of the casualty there is a claim for reimbursement with a reasonable expectation of recovering funds, the loss is not sustained until you know with reasonable certainty that you will receive such reimbursement. If you expect partial or full reimbursement of the loss, you must subtract the amount of the expected reimbursement when calculating the loss. You must reduce the loss even if you do not receive the payment until a subsequent tax year. See the section below titled Reimbursed Received After Deduction of a Loss.

If your property is insured, you must submit a claim for loss to the insurance company in a timely manner. If you do not submit a claim for loss to the insurance company, you cannot deduct the entire loss that you were unable to recover as a casualty or theft loss and you can only deduct the part of the loss that is not covered by your insurance policy. The part of the loss that is not usually covered by insurance (for example, a deductible) is not subject to this rule.
The most common type of reimbursement is insurance payments for stolen or damaged goods.Other types of reimbursement are explained below.See also the Instructions for Form 4684.

If you receive money from your employer's disaster relief fund and have to use that money to repair or replace property for which you claim a casualty loss deduction, you must take that amount into account when calculating the casualty loss deduction.

If you, as a victim of a disaster, receive tax-exempt cash gifts and there are no limits on how you can use the money, do not reduce the casualty loss with this type of gift.This applies even if you use the money to pay for repairs to property damaged in the disaster.

Do not reduce the loss of your main residence by using payments you have received from your insurance to cover maintenance expenses in any of the following two situations: if you lose the use of your main residence due to a casualty; if you are denied access to your main residence by the authorities because of a casualty or because of the threat of a casualty.

The taxable part of the insurance payment is included as income in the year in which you return to use your main dwelling or, if later, in the year in which you receive the taxable part of the insurance payment.
Do not reduce your casualty loss by borrowing funds used to rehabilitate or replace the property for which you are claiming the casualty loss deduction.

If you calculated your loss from a mishap or theft using the expected refund amount, you may need to adjust your tax return for the tax year in which you actually receive your refund. This section explains the adjustments you may need to make. If you paid any amount to repair damage to a deteriorated concrete foundation home for personal use and claimed a deduction on your original or amended income tax return and payments were made to you (or on your behalf to contractors) by the Connecticut Foundation Solutions Indemnity Company (CFSIC), you have to include some or all of the payments in your gross income. See the 2020-5 Announcement (Notice 2020-5), which is found on Internal page 796 of the 2020-19 Revenue Bulletin (www.cfn.gov.gov/2020-19#IRB/IRB/IRB/IRB/IRB/IRB/IRB/IRB/IRB/IRB/IRB/IRB/IRB/IRB/IRB/IRB/IRB/IRB/IRB/IRB) and is available for more information.

If you later receive a refund that turns out to be more than the expected amount after you claimed a loss deduction, you may have to include the amount of the additional refund in your income for the year you received it. However, if any part of the original deduction did not reduce your taxes for the previous year, do not include that part of the refund amount in your income.
If you later receive a refund for the exact amount you expected to receive, you do not have to include any amount in your income and you cannot deduct any additional loss.

There are two ways to deduct a loss of inventory from a fortuitous event or theft, including items you have for sale to customers. One way is to deduct the loss through the increase in the cost of goods sold, properly reporting the initial inventory and closing inventory. Do not re-declare this loss as a loss from a fortuitous event or theft. If you take the loss through the increase in the cost of goods sold, include any insurance or other reimbursements you receive for that loss in your gross receipts. The other way is to deduct the loss. If you deduct it this way, remove the affected inventory items from the cost of goods sold, making a decrease adjustment to the initial inventory or purchases. Reduce the loss by the refund received. Do not include the refund in the gross receipts. If you do not have a reasonable expectation for the loss, you will not be able to recover the loss until you have received a reasonable amount of the loss. If you have not received the receipt, you will not be able to recover the loss until you have received a reasonable amount of the loss.

If you are liable for casualty damage to a property you rent, your loss is the amount you have to pay to repair the property less any insurance or other reimbursement you receive or expect to receive.

Generally, if a single accident or theft affects more than one item of property, you will need to calculate the loss of each item separately.Then, add up the losses to determine the total amount of loss from that accident or theft.

Fair market value (FMV) is the price at which you could sell your goods to a willing buyer when neither of you has to sell or buy and both of you know all the relevant facts. The fair market value decrease used to calculate the amount of loss due to accident or theft is the difference between the fair market value of the goods immediately before and immediately after the accident or theft occurs.

If you recover property after you have included a theft loss deduction, you must recalculate the loss using the lesser amount between the adjusted basis of the property (which is explained below) or the decrease in fair market value from the time immediately before it was stolen to the time it was recovered. Use this amount to recalculate the total loss for the year in which the loss was deducted. If the amount of the recalculated loss is less than the loss you deducted, you generally have to declare the difference as income in the year in which you recovered it.

To calculate the fair market value decrease due to a fortuitous event or theft, you usually need a competent (faithful) appraisal. However, other measures may also be employed to establish certain decreases. See the topics Appraisals, Cleaning and Repair Costs and Special Procedure  Safe Harbor Methods for Determining Losses from Theft or Fortuitous Event presented below.

You could use an appraisal used to obtain a federal government loan (or a federal loan guarantee) as a result of a disaster declared as such by the federal government to establish the amount of your disaster loss.

The cost of repairing damaged property is not part of the loss for contingency. Neither is the cost of cleaning up after a contingency. But you can use the cost of cleaning up or making repairs after a contingency as a measure of the decrease in fair market value if all of the following conditions are met: The repairs are actually made. The repairs are necessary to bring the property back to its pre-contingency condition. The amount spent on repairs is not excessive. The repairs are made solely to repair the damage. The value of the property after the repairs are made is not, because of such repairs, greater than the value of the property before the contingency occurred.

The cost of restoring gardens to their original condition after a fortuitous event could indicate decreased fair market value. You may be able to measure the loss by what you spend on the following activities: Removing destroyed or damaged trees and shrubs, minus any residual value you received for that item. Pruning and taking other measures in order to conserve damaged trees and shrubs. Replanting, if necessary, to restore the property to its approximate value before the fortuitous event occurred.

The books of various automobile organizations that include information about the model and manufacturer of your car can be useful in calculating the value of the car. You can use the retail values of your vehicle that appear in the books and modify them according to factors such as mileage and the condition of your vehicle to calculate the value of the car. The prices are not official, but they could be useful in determining the value of the car and suggest relative prices that serve as a comparison with current sales and offers in your area. If your car is not listed in those books, determine the value based on other sources. The offer you receive from a dealer for your car as part of the payment for a new one is usually not a calculation of its actual value.

To calculate the amount of theft or fortuitous loss, you typically have to determine the decrease in the fair market value of the lost or damaged property by means of a competent appraisal or using the cost of repairs you actually make. However, the special safe harbor methods in Revenue Procedure 2018-08 found on page 286 of the Internal Revenue Bulletin 2018-02 allow you to determine the decrease in fair market value in other ways. The fortuitous losses of personal use property held by an individual are deductible only if they are attributable to a disaster declared by the federal government as such. An exception to the federal rule limiting the fortuitous personal use deduction to the point that personal use deductions for personal use property cannot be attributed to you if you have lost such property in a disaster.

If you have been charged with a crime, the IRS will not dispute your determination. If you are eligible to use and do use the safe harbor methods described in Revenue Procedure 2018-08, the IRS will not dispute your determination. Using the safe harbor methods described in Revenue Procedure 2018-08 is not mandatory.

The replacement cost safe harbor method for federally declared disasters allows you to determine the fair market value of your personal use belongings located in a disaster area, immediately prior to a federally declared disaster, to calculate the amount of your loss by accident or theft. To use such replacement cost safe harbor method, you must first determine the current cost to replace your personal use belonging with a new one and then reduce that amount by 10% for each year that you have owned the personal use belonging.

The loss determined by the safe harbour methods is to be reduced by the value of any repairs provided by a third party at no cost to you (for example, work done by volunteers or through donations).In addition, you are to reduce your loss by the amount of any insurance, reimbursement or other compensation you receive.

When completing Form 4684, do not enter an amount on line 5 or line 6 for each property. Instead, enter the decrease in fair market value determined according to the safe harbor method on line 7. For losses from Hurricane Harvey, Hurricane Irma, and Hurricane Maria, see Revenue Procedure 2018-09 (Tax Administrative Procedure 2018-09), which is found on page 290 of the Internal Revenue Bulletin 2018-02 (Tax Bulletin 2018-02), available at IRS.gov/BIRB/2018#2-09 for the safe harbor method insurance cost indexes.

In general, a residential property for personal use is real property, including improvements, which is owned by the individual who suffered a casualty loss and in which there is at least one residence for personal use. This does not include a residence for personal use if any part of it is used as rental property or if it has an office used for an office or business or any transaction in which it is engaged for profit. For more details, see Revenue Procedure 2018-08. The safe harbor methods for residential real estate for personal use available through Revenue Procedure 2018-08 are: Estimated cost for repair (Estimated cost repair method), federal de minimis method (De minimis method), harbor method (De minimis method), safe harbor method (Federally declared disaster insurance method), government disaster loan (Federally declared disaster insurance method), FISD method (Federally declared disaster insurance method), FISD method (Federally declared disaster insurance method), FISD method (Federally declared disaster insurance method), FISD method (Federally declared disaster insurance method), FISD method (Federally declared disaster insurance method), FISD method method) or FISD method (Federally declared disaster insurance method).

The safe harbor method of estimated cost of repair allows you to calculate the decrease in the fair market value of your residential real estate property for personal use using the lesser of two repair estimates prepared by different independent and licensed contractors.The estimates must list the detailed costs of restoring your property to its condition immediately prior to the accident.The safe harbor method of estimated cost of repair is limited to casualty losses of $20,000 or less.

The insurance safe harbor method allows you to calculate the decrease in the fair market value of your residential personal property based on the estimated loss in reports prepared by your homeowners insurance company or your flood insurance company. These reports are meant to establish the estimated loss you sustained due to damage or destruction to your property.

If the loss occurred in a disaster area and was due to a federally declared disaster, then you can use the contractor safe harbor method or the disaster loan appraisal method. Under the contractor safe harbor method, you can use the cost for repairs specified in a contract prepared by an independent and licensed contractor to determine the decrease in the fair market value of your residential real estate for personal use. This safe harbor method does not apply unless it is subject to a binding contract, signed by you and the contractor, setting forth the detailed costs to restore your residential real estate for personal use to its condition immediately prior to the event.

Under the safe harbor method of disaster loan appraisal, you can use a prepared appraisal to obtain a federal government loan (or a federal loan guarantee) that identifies your estimated loss as a result of a federally declared disaster to determine the decline in the fair market value of your residential real estate for personal use.

Personal property generally includes items of tangible personal property of an individual who suffered a casualty loss or theft, if those belongings are not used in a trade or business.[1] Personal property does not include items whose value is sustained or increased by the passage of time or other types of property.[2] For more details, see Revenue Procedure 2018-08 (Tax Administrative Procedure 2018-08).[3] The safe harbor methods for personal property are the de minimis method and the replacement cost method for federally declared disasters.[4]
The following items should not generally be taken into account when calculating the fair market value decrease in your property.

The cost of protecting your property against a casualty or theft is not part of casualty or theft losses. The amount you spend to protect your home from storms, whether in insurance or by placing planks on windows, is not part of the loss. If the property is commercial property, these expenses can be deducted as business expenses. If you make permanent improvements to your property to protect against a casualty or theft, add the cost of these improvements to the property's base. An example would be the cost of a dam to prevent flooding.

The accounting balance sheet value of the assets held by the reporting institution that are not held by the reporting institution and that are not reported in the balance sheet shall be reported in this item.

Unforeseen expenses you incur because of a mishap or theft, such as personal injury treatment, temporary housing, or car rental expenses, are not part of your mishap or theft loss.However, they may be deductible as business expenses if the damaged or stolen property is commercial property.

Do not take sentimental value into account when calculating your loss.If a family portrait, inherited items, or mementos have been damaged, destroyed, or stolen, you must base your loss only on the fair market value of these goods, as limited by their adjusted basis in ownership.

The loss of property due to a casualty is not deductible for actual property damage, but if your home is located in a federally declared disaster area, see the section entitled "Losses in Disaster Areas" below.

For example, if you have a property that has been damaged, you may be able to determine the value of the property by using photographs taken after the accident occurred to establish the condition and value of the property after the damage occurred.

The degree of investment you have in the property you own is the basis.In the case of property you buy, the basis is usually what it costs you.If you acquire property in some other way, for example, as an inheritance, gift or non-taxable exchange, you have to calculate the basis in another way, as explained in Publication 551.

If you inherited property from someone who died in 2010 and the estate executor chose to make a Section 1022 election using Form 8939, Allocation of Increase in Basis for Property Acquired From a Decedent, special rules related to the estate will apply to you. The estate executor of a deceased person who died in 2010 may choose to apply a modified transferred basis treatment to the estate of the deceased person. For more detailed information about the Section 1022 Election, see Notice 2011-66 found on page 184 of the Internal Revenue Bulletin 2011-35 (available at IRS.gov.b/NOB/2011/BIRT-335/BIRT-41-31 (disposable at IRS.gov.b/BIRT-335/BIRT-41/11) For information about tax-deductible deposits made by entities, see the Internal Revenue Code 2011-01-32 (disposable at IRS.gov.b/BIRT-335/BIRT-41/11) for information on tax-deductible deposits made by entities entered into the Internal Revenue Procedure 2011-102 (disposed by entities entered into the IRS by entities entered into the IRS).

During the time you own your property, several events can occur that change the basis. Some of these increase the basis, such as extensions or permanent improvements to the property. Others, such as casualty losses and prior depreciation deductions, decrease the basis. Adding the increases to the basis and subtracting the decreases from it, the result is the adjusted basis.

After calculating the amount of your casualty loss or theft, you need to calculate what percentage of the loss you can deduct. The federal casualty loss and theft deduction for personal use property is limited. For the 2018 to 2025 tax years, casualty losses of personal use property sustained by an individual are deductible only to the extent that they are attributable to a disaster declared as such by the federal government. The casualty loss or theft of personal use property attributable to a disaster declared as such by the federal government is limited under the $100 per each casualty rule and the 10% deductible rule, explained below. The $100 and 10% deductible loss rules are also summarized in Table 2. A single casualty is considered when the damage is derived from two or more directly related causes, such as wind damage and flooding from the same storm. If two or more persons (other than spouses filing jointly) suffer a loss of property in a jointly owned property, the $100 rule applies separately to each of them.For example, if two sisters live in a house they bought together and have a casual loss of property in the house, each sister must apply the $100 rule separately.

You must deduct 10% of your adjusted gross income from your total federal casualty loss. Apply this rule after you have deducted $100 from each loss. If the loss is greater than the amount of the loss recognised, deduct the gain from the loss and deduct 10% of your adjusted gross income from the income. When the property is used partly for personal use and partly for commercial or income-generating purposes, the casualty loss or theft deduction for the personal use portion and the commercial or income-generating portion must be calculated separately, since the losses attributed to these two uses are calculated differently. When calculating each loss, allocate between the commercial and personal use of the property the total cost or basis, the fair market value before and after the casualty loss or theft, and the amount covered by insurance or other reimbursement. If you make a gain because your primary residence was destroyed, you can generally exclude the gain from your income as if you had sold or exchanged it. If the tax filing deadline is deferred, the IRS will announce this deferral in your area through a press release and, as necessary, in tax rulings, tax filing procedures, notices, and other communications in the Internal Revenue Service's (IRS) Internal Revenue Revenue Bulletin (IRB) or its Interim Revenue Service's (IRS) Tax Return/Revenue Relief button, if available, to help you determine your tax return.

If you wish to revoke a power of attorney that is in effect and you do not wish to appoint a new representative, you must write "REVOKE" at the top of the first page of Form 2848 with the current signature and date immediately below this annotation. You must then mail or fax a copy of the power of attorney with the annotation on the revocation to the IRS as indicated in the table entitled Where to File the Form, Instructions for Form 2848 SP, or, if the power of attorney is for a specific matter, to the IRS office handling the matter. If you do not have a copy of the power of attorney you wish to revoke, you must send the IRS a statement of revocation stating that the power of attorney was revoked, the years and matters or periods mentioned are written, and the full name and address of each representative whose power of attorney was revoked is noted immediately below this annotation. If you wish to revoke this statement, you must specify the years/periods in which the power of attorney was revoked and the date of each year in which the power of attorney was revoked.

If your representative wishes to withdraw from representation, the representative must write "WITHDRAW" at the top of the first page of Form 2848 with the current signature and date immediately below the notation. The representative must then provide a copy of the power of attorney with the notation on the withdrawal to the IRS as described in the Taxpayer Withdrawal section, above. If your representative does not have a copy of the power of attorney you wish to withdraw, the representative must send the IRS a written statement indicating the withdrawal stating that the power of attorney is withdrawn, recording the matters and years or periods, and mentioning the name, taxpayer identification number (TIN), and address (if known) of the representative. The representative must sign and certify the written statement.
